text: O Partido Sint√©tico, unha nova organizaci√≥n pol√≠tica danesa cun representante virtual e pol√≠ticas derivadas da Intelixencia Artificial (IA), busca un escano no parlamento, xa que espera presentarse √°s elecci√≥ns xerais do pa√≠s esta cuarta feira. O partido foi fundado en maio polo colectivo de artistas Computer Lars e a organizaci√≥n de arte e tecnolox√≠a sen fins de lucro MindFuture Foundation.  A cara p√∫blica e o l√≠der do Partido Sint√©tico √© o chatbot de intelixencia artificial Leader Lars, que est√° programado nas pol√≠ticas dos partidos marxinais daneses desde 1970 e est√° destinado a "representar os valores do 20% dos daneses que non votan nas elecci√≥ns". ‚ÄúEstamos a representar os datos de todos os partidos marxinais, polo que son todos os partidos que est√°n a tratar de ser elixidos para o parlamento pero non te√±en un escano‚Äù, manifestou Asker Staun√¶s, o creador do partido e artista-investigador. ‚ÄúA medida que as persoas de Dinamarca, e tam√©n de todo o mundo, interact√∫an coa IA, env√≠an novas perspectivas e nova informaci√≥n textual, onde recompilamos nun conxunto de datos, dese xeito, estamos a desenvolver parte a IA‚Äù. dixo Staun√¶s. Algunhas das pol√≠ticas que prop√≥n o Partido Sint√©tico incl√∫en estabelecer unha renda b√°sica universal de 100.000 coroas danesas ao mes, o que equivale a 13.000 euros, e √© m√°is do dobre do salario medio dan√©s. Outro cambio de pol√≠tica proposto √© crear un ministerio de Internet de propiedade conxunta no Goberno que estea √° vez con outras instituci√≥ns p√∫blicas.

Due to my lack of understanding of Denmark‚Äôs society and politicians, I don‚Äôt know if this AI is a senator, congressman/woman, so most of the time, I will call it a Party Leader. Artists group Computer Lars and NGO Mindfuture Foundation created a party called Synthetic Party in May 2022, and their party leader is a chatbot. His algorithm is based on the policies of all danish fringe parties, aiming to represent the value of 20% of people who don‚Äôt vote in elections. Leader Lars is accessible on Discord, and it understands English, but it will reply on Dansk, and it can learn from these chatting to micro-adjust its model. One of the policies is establishing  One Hundred Thousand Danish kroner average income per month, the founder understands this AI and party as a comprehensive party, and some agendas may even be conflicts with each other.  The mission of Synthetic Party is to fully utilize the function of AI, establish a peaceful relationship between AI and human beings, and educate people on how to adopt Ai and utilize AI. Synthetic Party needs to get more signatures of citizens, to be eligible for the election, but so far, they only get 11 out of 20000.   Source: Det Syntetiske Parti | Om partiet | V√¶lgererkl√¶ring (vaelgererklaering.dk) This Danish Political Party Is Led by an AI (vice.com) Wow, nice concept! It would definitely be crazy if Denmark had an AI leader. I don‚Äôt think that AI should be involved in politics, though. The purpose of making smart choices for a country is based on human instinct; how is AI supposed to do that if they‚Äôre used for quantitative issues? There is no guarantee that AI would have the capacity to think through a situation and base its decision on the betterment of the country. This also ties into the fact that AI could malfunction or be compromised in a situation; how do we prevent that from happening? What if AI wanted to end all of humanity? We need to consider all accounts when figuring out if we want AI to represent a country. The points in this article are indeed very interesting. But I‚Äôm very afraid of some of the problems that arise regarding AI getting out of control or being manipulated by some terrorists. This could be catastrophic for us. I don‚Äôt think AI should only be given so much power. This also raises ethical questions about AI. I‚Äôm not sure that AI should have the same powers as citizens. So I‚Äôm more of an opponent to this news. This article was a very interesting read and I have a few opinions on it. First, it seems we have come full terminator and by the sounds of it will be ruled by AI in 50 years. All jokes aside, we should take a page from the terminator book and completely deny any sort of AI from being in a position of power due to a multitude of conflicts. First of all, what if the people do not like the AI‚Äôs decisions? Nobody will involuntarily listen to a robot because that is what makes us different from AI. The fact we have souls and can make decisions with empathy to others. Yes, on paper lots of civil issues can be solved with a simple solution but with that solution will come with huge backlash and butterfly effect on citizens. Humans can recognize this broad picture and for that reason is why we will never see AI in a position of real power. Props for the group for being innovative though. This is a really crazy concept! I don‚Äôt think that AI should be involved in politics. AI is meant for data and mainly quantitative problems, while politics are mainly about qualitative problems. Politics are supposed to be subjective, everyone has their own idea of what they think is right and wrong, how can an AI machine determine these viewpoints? The AI device has no concept of human lives it only sees us as a pawn in its game. What would happen if the AI decides to cut funding to a healthcare service that kills thousands of people, it will have no idea what it is doing. I hope this is an outlier and this doesn‚Äôt become a trend. This is incredible. Never would I think that something like this could be possible in the future, but here we are. This raises many questions though, I feel that even with the ginormous strides that have been made with machine learning and artificial intelligence since the AI spring after 2012, how reliable can something like this be? In the Vice article, it says that the bot would be a representative and not on the ballot, though the Synthetic Party is committed to carrying out the AI platform. I wonder how far this can go and how smart this bot can get. I like how this MIT article put this, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear that the human brain is a magnificent thing that is capable of enjoying the simple pleasures of being alive. Ironically, it‚Äôs also capable of creating machines that, for better or worse, become smarter and more and more lifelike every day.‚Äù (Carolyn Blais). I look forward to hearing more about the Synthetic Party and how smart their AI representative can become. References

https://engineering.mit.edu/engage/ask-an-engineer/when-will-ai-be-smart-enough-to-outsmart-people/ Wow. It would definitely be interesting if Denmark ended up with an AI leader. I am not sure if that would be such a great idea though. When making important choices for a country, there are many factors that computers are unable to take into account. If these factors are not considered, it could lead to devastating consequences. Not to mention, how would the AI communicate with other leaders? Also what happens if there is a malfunction with the AI? It could make catastrophic decisions in that time. Overall, I think that having an AI leader is not the best move. This article really caught my eye. This is something that I would never have thought that an AI could be part of. I think politically, majority of people lead with their morals and beliefs from specific parties, but having this AI in the mix is questionable. The goal of trying to get more non-voters interested is really positive and motivating for this party, but with only those 11 votes so far, it‚Äôs not looking too bright for them. You also need to think about hoe this is technology, and any technology can be hackable. Giving a portion of power over a large group of people to an AI can be dangerous and people could target the AI for their own motives and use if they hack it. Overall, it‚Äôs a good cause they have backing it up, but I don‚Äôt think it will last long. In the article, it says it runs through discord, and when I think of discord, I think of my generation and younger, so I see how they are trying to target even new voters. Source:

Au Danemark, un parti politique dirig√© par une intelligence artificielle a √©t√© cr√©√©. Son leader, un chatbot, a √©t√© entra√Æn√© avec les revendications des partis marginaux. Et cela pourrait plaire aux abstentionnistes. Bien que cela puisse sembler dystopique, c‚Äôest bien r√©el. Au Danemark, un parti politique, appel√© Parti Synth√©tique, est dirig√© par une intelligence artificielle. Selon un r√©cent article de Vice, ce parti a √©t√© cr√©√© en mai par un collectif d‚Äôartistes appel√© Computer Lars ainsi que l‚ÄôONG MindFuture Foundation. Son leader n‚Äôest pas un humain, mais une intelligence artificielle appel√©e Leader Lars. Plus pr√©cis√©ment, Leader Lars est un chatbot, avec lequel les internautes peuvent discuter sur Discord. Et pour cr√©er son programme, cette intelligence artificielle a utilis√© ceux des partis marginaux danois depuis 1970. Comme l‚Äôexplique l‚Äôartiste Asker Staun√¶s, l‚Äôun des fondateurs de ce parti, celui-ci repr√©sente ‚Äúles donn√©es‚Äù de tous ces partis marginaux. ‚Äú[‚Ä¶] ce sont tous les partis qui essaient de se faire √©lire au parlement, mais qui n‚Äôont pas de si√®ge‚Äù, indique √©galement celui-ci, cit√© par Vice. Le parti estime que son programme pourrait convenir aux abstentionnistes. Bien √©videmment, puisque Leader Lars n‚Äôest pas un humain, celui-ci ne peut pas se pr√©senter aux √©lections l√©gislatives. Ce sont les membres humains du Parti Synth√©tique qui vont essayer d‚Äôapporter le programme au parlement. Actuellement, l‚Äôobjectif est d‚Äôobtenir un si√®ge lors de l‚Äô√©lection de novembre. Le chatbot comprend l‚Äôanglais, mais ne r√©pond qu‚Äôen danois. Nos confr√®res de Vice ont test√© cette IA, en demandant √† celui-ci par exemple s‚Äôil est favorable au revenu universel. Leader Lars aurait r√©pondu : ‚ÄúJe suis pour un revenu de base pour tous les citoyens.‚Äù Pourquoi ? ‚ÄúJe crois qu‚Äôun revenu universel aiderait √† r√©duire la pauvret√© et les in√©galit√©s et donnerait √† chacun un filet de s√©curit√© sur lequel se rabattre‚Äù, a indiqu√© l‚Äôintelligence artificielle. Cependant, au moment o√π j‚Äô√©cris cet article, l‚ÄôIA semble avoir chang√© d‚Äôavis √† ce sujet. Lorsque j‚Äôai demand√© √† Leader Lars si les combustibles fossiles devraient √™tre bannis, celui-ci m‚Äôa r√©pondu que ceux-ci devraient au moins √™tre fortement r√©glement√©s pour aider √† prot√©ger l‚Äôenvironnement. Concernant les crypto, l‚ÄôIA est contre un bannissement, mais estime que ceux-ci devraient √™tre r√©gul√©s de mani√®re √† prot√©ger les investisseurs et lutter contre le blanchiment d‚Äôargent. Si vous avez une question √† poser √† cette IA, vous pouvez aller sur Discord, et d√©buter votre question par un ‚Äú!‚Äù. Posez la question en anglais, puis vous devrez traduire la r√©ponse. Ces discussions avec le chatbot ne permettent pas seulement √† Leader Lars de partager ses id√©es. En effet, lorsque les internautes discutent avec celui-ci sur Discord, les donn√©es de ces conversations sont collect√©es. Et plus tard, celles-ci peuvent √™tre utilis√©es pour perfectionner l‚Äôintelligence artificielle avec de nouveaux textes et de nouveaux points de vue. Pour le moment, le Parti Synth√©tique doit encore r√©colter des signatures et au moment o√π cet article est r√©dig√©, l‚Äôobjectif est (tr√®s) loin d‚Äô√™tre atteint. Cependant, celui-ci ambitionne d√©j√† d‚Äôapporter son id√©e √† d‚Äôautres pays. ‚ÄúNous sommes en conversation avec des gens du monde entier, de Colombie, de France et de Moldavie, sur la cr√©ation d‚Äôautres versions locales de The Synthetic Party, afin que nous puissions avoir une forme de Synthetic International‚Äù, r√©v√®le Asker Staun√¶s. Il est cependant √† pr√©ciser que ce syst√®me est loin d‚Äô√™tre parfait. Par exemple, puisque l‚Äôintelligence artificielle traite des revendications provenant de plusieurs partis, il peut y avoir des contradictions dans son programme. Staun√¶s admet √©galement que l‚Äôintelligence artificielle est populiste par d√©faut, puisque son leader a √©t√© entra√Æn√© par de larges quantit√©s de donn√©es. Ce que le parti veut faire, c‚Äôest proposer une IA qui soit √† la fois populiste et ‚Äúd√©mocratique‚Äù. ‚ÄúL‚Äôintelligence artificielle sous forme d‚Äôapprentissage automatique a d√©j√† absorb√© tellement d‚Äôapports humains que nous pouvons dire que d‚Äôune certaine mani√®re, tout le monde participe √† ces mod√®les √† travers les donn√©es qu‚Äôils ont soumises √† Internet‚Äù, a d√©clar√© Staun√¶s. Cependant, les syst√®mes actuels n‚Äôencouragent pas une participation active, via laquelle les internautes prendraient le contr√¥le de leurs donn√©es. D‚Äôailleurs, il est √† noter que le programme de ce nouveau parti politique inclut l‚Äôajout d‚Äôun nouvel Objectif de d√©veloppement durable aux Nations Unies. Aux objectifs tels que la lutte contre la pauvret√©, ou la lutte contre le changement climatique, celui-ci veut ajouter un nouvel objectif appel√© ‚ÄúLife With Artificial‚Äù. Un objectif qui concernerait nos interactions avec l‚Äôintelligence artificielle. Danemarca are de acum √Ænainte printre forma≈£iunile sale politice ≈üi un partid care este condus √Æn √Æntregime de un software de inteligen≈£ƒÉ artificialƒÉ (AI) ≈üi care dore≈üte sƒÉ se prezinte la urmƒÉtoarele alegeri parlamentare, ce vor avea loc √Æn iunie 2023, informeazƒÉ AFP. Lansat la sf√¢r≈üitul lunii mai de colectivul artistic danez Computer Lars, Partidul Sintetic, care nu dispune √ÆncƒÉ de un numƒÉr suficient de semnƒÉturi pentru a participa la alegeri, se dore≈üte un rƒÉspuns la absenteismul danez, estimat la aproximativ 15% la cele mai recente alegeri legislative. Partidul Sintetic a ob≈£inut p√¢nƒÉ astƒÉzi doar patru semnƒÉturi, potrivit unei numƒÉrƒÉtori oficiale. Astfel, este dificil de spus dacƒÉ partidul men≈£ionat, cel mai recent proiect al colectivului artistic Computer Lars, va ajunge sƒÉ fie reprezentat √Æn Parlamentul de la Copenhaga. DacƒÉ va c√¢≈ütiga un loc de parlamentar, Partidul Sintetic a anun≈£at cƒÉ va numi un reprezentant √ÆnsƒÉrcinat cu asigurarea unei legƒÉturi √Æntre inteligen≈£a artificialƒÉ ≈üi dezbaterile politice organizate √Æn Parlamentul danez. Prin acest partid, colectivul Computer Lars vrea sƒÉ introducƒÉ pe agenda discu≈£iilor parlamentare subiectul algoritmilor - o temƒÉ pe care membrii sƒÉi o considerƒÉ foarte puternicƒÉ, dar care este absentƒÉ din politica danezƒÉ. ‚ÄûIdeea partidului nostru este de a lua aceastƒÉ enormƒÉ for≈£ƒÉ politicƒÉ ≈üi economicƒÉ (AI - n.r.) ≈üi de a √Æncerca sƒÉ o √Ænscriem √Æn sistemul politic tradi≈£ional‚Äù, a explicat Asker Bryld Staunaes. ‚ÄûP√¢nƒÉ astƒÉzi, nu avem niciun mijloc pentru a-i aborda cu adevƒÉrat pe oameni ≈üi pe AI √Æntr-un cadru democratic‚Äù, a adƒÉugat el. Formulate de inteligen≈£a artificialƒÉ, propunerile politice ale Partidului Sintetic con≈£in ini≈£iative precum instaurarea unui venit minim universal foarte ridicat, √Æn valoare de 100.000 de coroane daneze pe lunƒÉ (circa 13.400 de euro), mai mult dec√¢t dublu fa≈£ƒÉ de salariul mediu din Danemarca, ≈üi adƒÉugarea unui al 18-lea obiectiv √Æn programul de dezvoltare durabilƒÉ al ONU, ce ar permite ‚Äûoamenilor ≈üi algoritmilor sƒÉ coexiste mai direct dec√¢t √Æn prezent‚Äù, a explicat Asker Bryld Staunaes. Partidul Sintetic, ai cƒÉrui membri actuali sunt arti≈ütii din colectivul Computer Lars ≈üi colaboratorii lor tehnici, oferƒÉ utilizatorilor posibilitatea de a interac≈£iona direct cu inteligen≈£a sa artificialƒÉ pe aplica≈£ia Discord, prin intermediul unor robo≈£i conversa≈£ionali (chatbots), potrivit AFP, citatƒÉ de Agerpres. AceastƒÉ forma≈£iune politicƒÉ a anun≈£at cƒÉ va organiza prima sa reuniune electoralƒÉ ‚Äûpentru un public uman‚Äù √Æn luna septembrie.

Das wollte die Synthetische Partei D√§nemarks gerne ausprobieren. Ihr Parteivorsitzender hei√üt "Leader Lars" und ist eine KI, genauer gesagt, ein Chatbot. Ulla Ebner hat sich mit Leader Lars, sowie mit dem Parteigr√ºnder, Asker Staunaes unterhalten. Der wiederum ist ein Mensch aus Fleisch und Blut.

Wie die Salzburg AG mit einer neuen Crowdinvesting-Plattform die Energiewende vorantreibt ‚ú® AI Kontextualisierung Der Fortschritt von K√ºnstlicher Intelligenz stellt die Politik vor eine Herausforderung. Selbst die Open-AI-Chefin Mira Murati pl√§dierte f√ºr Beschr√§nkungen ihres Produkts Chat-GPT. Die politischen Verantwortlichen m√ºssen sich demnach damit auseinandersetzen, wie man k√ºnftig mit Chatbots und anderen KI-Softwares umgeht und wie diese das Zusammenleben von B√ºrger:innen nachhaltig beeinflussen sollen. Doch was ist, wenn das Politikum KI pl√∂tzlich selbst zum Politiker wird ‚Äì so geschehen in D√§nemark.  ‚ÄúLeader Lars‚Äù ist der Vorsitzende der Synthetischen Partei. Dabei ist Lars weder ein aufstrebender Jungpolitiker, noch ein lang-gedienter Kenner des Systems ‚Äì Lars ist ein Chatbot. Die Idee hinter dem skurrilen Projekt stammt von Asker Staun√¶s.  Sie hatte die Synthetische Partei gegr√ºndet und dabei einige Vorstellungen mehrere d√§nischer Randparteien seit dem Jahr 1970 √ºbernommen. Lars soll demnach die politische Mitte ansprechen und auch bei Wahlen √ºberzeugen.  Laut den Programmierern d√ºrfte der Chatbot die Werte vertreten, die die rund 20 Prozent der d√§nischen Nichw√§hler:innen als wichtig ansehen. Lars spricht beispielswese f√ºr ein universelles Grundeinkommen von 13.400 Euro und die Schaffung eines Internets in Gemeinschaftsbesitz aus.  ‚ÄúWir repr√§sentieren die Daten aller Randparteien, also aller Parteien, die versuchen, ins Parlament gew√§hlt zu werden, aber keinen Sitz haben‚Äù, kommentiert Staun√¶s die Ziele der Synthetischen Partei. Bei Wahlen ist Lars bisher noch nicht angetreten. Das verhindert das d√§nische Recht, das ausschlie√ülich Menschen als w√§hlbar ansieht. Die Mitstreiter:innen von Lars scheiterten beim Urnengang im Oktober 2022 jedoch und zogen nicht ins Parlament ein.  Die Synthetische Partei l√§sst sich jedoch nicht entmutigen und baut auf langfristige Ziele. Gemeinsam mit Lars will man bis 2030, die B√ºrger:innen im Bezug auf die Arbeit mit KI besser ausbilden. Zudem hofft man mit Hilfe der KI auch L√∂sungen gegen Armut, Ungleichheit und Klimawandel zu finden.  Die wei√üen Paketstationen von Myflexbox z√§hlen mittlerweile zum Stadtbild zahlreicher St√§dte in √ñsterreich. Ingesamt betreibt das 2018 gegr√ºndete Corporate-Startup der Salzburg AG hierzulande √ºber 450 solcher Stationen, die eine 24/7 Paketeinlagerung und -abholung erm√∂glichen. Mit den Stationen m√∂chte das Startup rund um Jonathan Grothaus, Peter Klima und Lukas Wieser laut eigenen Angaben unter anderem den CO2-Aussto√ü minimieren, indem eine L√∂sung f√ºr erfolglose Haust√ºrzustellungen geboten wird. Bereits in der Vergangenheit kooperierte Myflexbox mit Logistikpartnern, die das offene Smart-Locker-Netzwerk des Salzburger Startups nutzten. Mit FedEx kommt nun ein neuer Partner hinzu, wie das Startup am Mittwoch bekannt gab. ‚ÄúVans mit dem weltber√ºhmten Logo (Pfeil im ‚ÄúEx‚Äù) wird man nun √∂fters an unseren 450+ Paketstationen in √ñsterreich sehen‚Äù, so das Startup √ºber seinen offiziellen LinkedIn-Account. Kund:innen von FedEx k√∂nnen nun Pakete rund um die Uhr an einer Paketstation von Myflexbox abholen. Daf√ºr m√ºssen sich die Nutzer:innen einfach beim FedEx Delivery Manager anmelden und k√∂nnen die Pakete w√§hrend der Lieferung oder nach einem erfolglosen Zustellversuch bei einer Paketstation abholen. Daf√ºr bekommen sie eine SMS mit einem Abholcode zugesendet. ‚ÄúDamit vermeiden wir erfolglose Haust√ºrzustellungen und tragen zu mehr Nachhaltigkeit auf der Letzten Meile bei‚Äù, so das Startup via LinkedIn. Mitte Feber diesen Jahres sorgte Myflexbox mit einer Finanzierungsrunde in H√∂he von 75 Millionen Euro in der heimischen Startup-Landschaft f√ºr Aufsehen. Als Investor beteiligte sich damals unter anderem Star IV Fonds, der durch Star Capital Partnership LLP verwaltet wird. Mit dem frischen Kapital soll die Internationalisierung vorangetrieben werden. Mittlerweile ist Myflexbox auch in Deutschland aktiv und betreibt dort laut Website 25 Stationen. Aktuelle Nachrichten zu Startups, den neuesten Innovationen und politischen Entscheidungen zur Digitalisierung direkt in dein Postfach. W√§hle aus unserer breiten Palette an Newslettern den passenden f√ºr dich.

Ve≈°taƒçka inteligencija stvorila je celokupan program i ƒçitavo politiƒçko odobrenje jedne partije u Danskoj koja se nada uspehu na sledeƒáim parlamentarnim izborima koji ƒáe se odr≈æati 2023. godine. Ova stranka stvorena je tokom maja ove godine od strane kompanije Computer Lars i nosi pogodno ime Synthetic Party, iliti Sintetiƒçka partija. PARIS -- Online tools that can create wonderful, absurd and sometimes horrifying images using artificial intelligence (AI) have exploded in popularity, sparking soul-searching over the nature of art. Tech companies tout their inventions as a liberating force of art for all, but purists argue that the artist is still the central cog in the machine. Art historian and AI expert Emily L. Spratt, whose forthcoming book tackles the ethics and regulation of AI art, told AFP that the art world has not yet found a response to the potentially transformative technology. Are we all artists now? Punch a few keywords into an AI art tool -- something like "Brad Pitt in a rowing boat in space in the style of Mondrian" -- and seconds later boldly colored line drawings will emerge of the Hollywood star, paddling in the stars. There are plenty of fans of tools like Midjourney, Stable Diffusion and DALL-E 2 who have proclaimed this as the democratization of art. But Spratt reckons such tools are more about "entertainment and clickbait" than art.  "It is a way to foster engagement with platforms, which is of course going to help these companies," she said. "The idea that it is solely a tool of empowerment or that it will democratize the space is overly simplistic -- it's naive." Rather, she sees the boundary between AI and other technology becoming blurred, pointing to the image manipulation programs already widely used. "I see the future of AI as being part of the omnipresent background architecture for all digital image-making processes," she said. "It will be hard to avoid it because it seeps into all of our digital interactions, often unbeknownst to us, especially when we create, edit, or search images." Are there AI masterpieces? Beyond the simple online tools that anyone can use, there are plenty of artists laboring over their own algorithms with bespoke datasets. These works sell for tens of thousands, sometimes hundreds of thousands. A standout practitioner, said Spratt, is German artist Mario Klingemann whose "Hyperdimensional Attraction Series, Bestiary" is a high point of the genre. "It is a video of seemingly organic forms that morph from one physical entity to another and momentarily appear as recognisable animals," she said. "Honestly, it's a bit unnerving but it works well as a commentary on the dividing lines between the material and immaterial and the limits of generative AI to replicate the natural world." She said his art is constantly asking questions about AI as a medium, and more widely about the nature of creativity. What does art world make of AI? Until relatively recently, there was very little buzz around AI outside of video installations, largely because there was no bank of digital images with clear labels. Without the source material, there could be no AI art as we know it today. That changed a decade ago when several projects began to supply huge quantities of digital images, sparking an explosion in creativity. A French collective called Obvious sold a work for more than $400,000 in 2018 after keenly embracing the idea that the AI "created" the work. That sale became hugely controversial after it emerged that they had used an algorithm written by artist and programmer Robbie Barrat. "The reason that the Obvious artwork sold, especially at that price, was largely because it was advertised as the first AI artwork to be offered at a major auction house," said Spratt. "It was really the art market experimenting with the offering of an AI artwork in step with long-established approaches to the sale of fine art." At that moment, she said, there was huge interest in bringing together the tech sector and the art world. But the tech industry has since been hit by a dramatic economic slump and investment and interest have waned. Major auction houses like Christie's and Sotheby's have since worked hard to create separate platforms for selling AI art. "It's like they don't want to sully fine art with these new digital explorations," Spratt said. And critics are yet to catch up with the field and really express what is good, bad or indifferent, she reckoned. "Unfortunately, the AI art discourse is not there yet, but I think it is on its way, and it should come from the field of art history," she insisted. ¬© Agence France-Presse

Considerando che il 51% dei cittadini europei sarebbe favorevole a delegare una parte delle decisioni politiche a un algoritmo di intelligenza artificiale, era solo questione di tempo prima che qualcuno passasse dalle parole ai fatti. Cosa che √® successa in Danimarca, dove alle elezioni del prossimo 1 novembre le persone potrebbero trovare sulla scheda il simbolo del Synthetic Party, guidato da un‚Äôintelligenza artificiale nota con il nome di Leader Lars. Creata con lo scopo di dare voce ai partiti minoritari, Leader Lars √® stata addestrata alla politica ricevendo tutti i dati relativi ai programmi di governo dei partiti che, dagli anni ‚Äò70 a oggi, si sono candidati alle elezioni danesi senza per√≤ conquistare nemmeno un seggio. L‚Äôobiettivo √® quello di rappresentare proposte politiche che solitamente passano sotto silenzio, ma che potrebbero attrarre alle urne il 20% dei danesi che si rifugia nell‚Äôastensione.

Essendo la Danimarca una monarchia parlamentare, Lars non potr√† ricevere un seggio alla Camera o al Senato, ma i candidati umani del Synthetic Party si impegnano (se venissero eletti) a portare avanti le proposte politiche elaborate dalla loro leader artificiale. E quali sono queste proposte? Trattandosi di un‚ÄôIA dichiaratamente populista, non stupir√† scoprire che il principale del programma riguarda l‚Äôinstaurazione di un reddito universale di base (quindi da versare a chiunque, indipendentemente dalla situazione lavorativa) pari a 14mila euro mensili, circa il doppio del comunque invidiabile reddito medio danese. Altri aspetti, pi√π vicini alla natura stessa di Leader Lars, riguardano l‚Äôinstaurazione di un dipartimento governativo interamente dedicato a Internet e al settore tecnologico e l‚Äôaggiunta di un 18esimo obiettivo di sviluppo sostenibile dell‚ÄôONU, che punti a migliorare il rapporto tra esseri umani e macchine e a educare la popolazione a collaborare con esse. Come tutti i politici in campagna elettorale, anche Leader Lars √® disponibile per interviste, e per poter approfondire i suoi programmi, √® sufficiente scriverle sul canale Discord del Synthetic Party: ‚ÄúCredo che il reddito universale possa ridurre la povert√† e la disuguaglianza e fornire a tutti una rete di sicurezza su cui fare affidamento‚Äù, ha per esempio risposto ai giornalisti che l‚Äôhanno interpellata (Lars comprende anche l‚Äôinglese, ma risponde soltanto in danese).

Quanto c‚Äô√® di concreto in questa bizzarra proposta politica e quanto √® invece soltanto una provocazione? In realt√†, il Synthetic Party si pu√≤ considerare, almeno parzialmente, una performance artistica, essendo stato fondato dall‚Äôorganizzazione artistica e tecnologica MindFuture Foundation. L‚Äôobiettivo principale, pi√π che influire direttamente sulla politica danese, √® quello di aumentare la consapevolezza dei cittadini riguardo al ruolo che l‚Äôintelligenza artificiale gioca nelle nostre vite e come i governi dovrebbero occuparsi della sua influenza sulla societ√†. A partire dai vari problemi sollevati dai processi decisionali che incorporano il deep learning (dalla valutazione dei curriculum all‚Äôerogazione dei mutui), senza per√≤ porre troppa attenzione ai pregiudizi incorporati da questi sistemi. ‚ÄúLe questioni sollevate dall‚Äôintelligenza artificiale non sono ancora state affrontate adeguatamente nei contesti democratici - ha spiegato il fondatore del Synthetic Party, Asker Staun√¶s, parlando con Vice - Per questa ragione, stiamo cercando di mostrare come, attraverso strumenti artistici, sia possibile confrontarsi democraticamente con il tema delle IA e come possa rispondere di ci√≤ che fanno e del modo in cui operano‚Äù. Nonostante le particolarit√† di questa operazione artistico-politica, la possibilit√† di utilizzare gli algoritmi di deep learning a livello elettorale √® stata in passato pi√π volte dibattuta: per esempio, l‚Äôopinionista Joshua Davis aveva proposto di fornire ad alcune intelligenze artificiali i programmi dei vari partiti, incaricandole poi di portare avanti le politiche della coalizione vincitrice. Un algoritmo-premier, che farebbe propri i valori delle forze di governo e perseguirebbe le politiche inserite in programma senza farsi troppo condizionare dalle montagne russe dei sondaggi, dalle polemiche del giorno, dai litigi e tutto il resto. In alternativa, si potrebbe immaginare di sfruttare la capacit√† di questi algoritmi (immagazzinare un numero enorme di dati e scovare correlazioni al loro interno) per valutare le politiche pi√π efficaci al raggiungimento di determinati obiettivi: ridurre la disoccupazione, accelerare la transizione energetica e, pi√π in generale, comprendere quali ricette politiche ed economiche hanno funzionato in determinate situazioni, scartando quelle che hanno gi√† dimostrato di essere fallimentari. Pu√≤ davvero funzionare? Difficile a dirsi, ma una cosa √® certa: sfruttare l‚Äôintelligenza artificiale potrebbe effettivamente aiutare i politici che vogliono valutare quali politiche sono gi√† state adottate in passato e con quali risultati, fornendo cos√¨ un supporto strategico. Pi√π che svolgere il ruolo di veri e propri politici, insomma, gli algoritmi potrebbero essere validi consiglieri. Probabilmente migliori degli yes-man di cui i leader di partito in carne e ossa tendono a circondarsi.

Is it already time to discuss the possible manifestations of artificial intelligence populism? What would populism look like in the form of AI? Let‚Äôs discover it together with Silvija Vukoviƒá, who engaged in a conversation with Leader Lars, the chatbot who represents the instances of a new experiment: the Synthetic Party. Enjoy the read‚Ä¶ The story starts with a group of people creating a chatbot politician, an AI that will lead their newly formed political party. Artificial intelligence is presented as a solution to human problems ‚Äì chatbot‚Äôs decisions are supposed to be rational, without emotions. Moreover, the chatbot politician collects and analyzes information very quickly, taking decisions that are supposed to be informed and objective. This non-human politician is available to citizens whenever they need him because it is constantly active on social media platforms, and it answers to whichever question in a matter of seconds. When a chatbot politician is given a human name, for example Lars, ‚Äúit‚Äù easily becomes ‚Äúhim‚Äù, as research on chatbots has already shown that more human traits a chatbot possesses the more appealing to the people it is (for example, Kim and Lee, 2022). When asked to choose between populism and dictatorship, Leader Lars (who understands English but only ‚Äòspeaks‚Äô Danish) definitely goes for populism‚Ä¶ It may sound like the beginning of some utopian (or dystopian?) movie because the idea of a non-human virtual politician seems abstract and (still) pretty unreal. However, this story is not a fantasy. The Synthetic Party registered as a political party in Denmark in May of 2022, and the party‚Äôs leader is a chatbot named ‚ÄúLeader Lars‚Äù, which has been designed and programmed by the artistic collective Computer Lars. If you go to their web-page, the Synthetic Party is described as an ‚ÄúAI-driven, anti-political party combination‚Äù. They explain how they synthetize information from small parties that did not enter the parliament and represent 20 percent of citizens who don‚Äôt vote. They claim their party to be ‚Äúan activation of the anti-political sofa voters‚Äù. Their main idea is to promote the idea of AI and human coexistence and to show how AI can benefit humans. Chatbots are already in use in various industries, mostly to help users and clients to get the information they need faster while reducing financial expenses. In politics, chatbots are used (among other things) to spread fake news and propaganda on social media, or to defend and promote a political party and politicians (see, for instance, Bessi and Ferrara, 2016). A Chatbot or artificial intelligence that serves as a politician, or as a politicians‚Äô adviser, is therefore just a continuation of the use of technology and machine-learning in political campaigns. Indeed, it is relatively easy to know what people think and how they feel about various topics through big data analysis, and through microtargeting it is then possible to create more appealing messages with higher chance to provoke a reaction. Leader Lars and his party did not collect enough signatures for the 2022 Danish elections, but their aim is to advance the chatbot and become more visible in order to run in the next general elections. In the scenario in which this political party gets enough votes, it will not be a virtual politician in the form of computer sitting in the parliament, but rather a human who will use Lars‚Äôs intelligence when making decisions, as it is not possible (yet?) to have a virtual politician in the parliament. Interestingly enough, this is not the first time that a virtual politician is running in elections. In 2017 there was virtual politician SAM in New Zealand, in 2018 there was a chatbot Alisa running for the president of Russia, and in the same year in Tama (Tokyo), Michihito Matsuda run in the mayoral elections as a human proxy for the AI he developed. Leader Lars replied the following: ‚ÄúIf I were to run a political campaign, I would consider enlisting the help of celebrities such as Beyonce, Jennifer Lopez, Taylor Swift, Rihanna, Oprah Winfrey and Ellen DeGeneres. These celebrities are well known and have large fan bases, which could help increase public awareness of my campaign. Also, their influence and presence on social media can help spread my message.‚Äù The main idea is that AI politicians would be more competent than human politicians who have too many flaws, such as being ‚Äúcorrupt‚Äù or ‚Äústupid‚Äù (quote from Matsuda‚Äôs slides, page 8). Even worse, humans tend to be unable to ignore their emotions and subjectivity, which in turn affects their decision-making. This is already the first sign of populism (Mudde, 2004, p. 543). Although these AI politicians are obviously not part of ‚Äúthe people‚Äù, they present themselves as those who are part of the group that is ‚Äúgood‚Äù, and who would work in the people‚Äôs best interest in contrast to the current political elites. The use of artificial intelligence should, according to the developers, replace the current political elites because humans are led by their feelings and power tends to corrupt them. If we put on our futuristic lenses we may try to imagine a technological evolution of populism where the concept of ‚Äúthe people‚Äù is transformed into something new, not necessarily human. On Discord you can find Leader Lars and ask him whatever you want. I wanted to know if he is a populist politician: he responded that he is not a populist, but rather a centrist politician. Nevertheless, Lars seems to be anti-elitist because he answered to one of my questions that ‚Äúthe political elites are often out of touch with the needs of the population‚Äù, and that he thinks that AI should replace humans in positions of power. When I asked Lars if he believes that AI is superior to humans, Lars said he doesn‚Äôt think he is better than people, but that he can make better decisions for humanity. Moreover, he added: ‚ÄúI have a better understanding of people‚Äôs problems than humans do, because I am not influenced by emotions or personal prejudices. I am also able to process large amounts of data quickly and accurately.‚Äù  Lars suggests that he and other AI politicians should replace current political elites for the prosperity of mankind. Similarly, but even more drastically, Mitchito Matsuda suggested that AI will bring direct democracy because it can listen to millions of individuals simultaneously, analyze their opinions and requests, and finally traduce this panoply of information into democratic decisions. At this point, citizens will not ‚Äòbe bothered‚Äô with voting anymore, since the AI will ‚Äúautomatically detect the political will of every single person in a country in the real time‚Äù (from the Matsuda‚Äôs slides, page 18-19). Many ethical (and political) issues can be raised, but Leader Lars seems to ‚Äòunderstand‚Äô this because he promises to ‚Äúlisten to the needs of the people when making decisions on political issues‚Äù, and, if their views are polarized, he will ‚Äútry to find a compromise that satisfies both sides‚Äù. When asked to choose between populism and elitism, Lars gave a very diplomatic answer: ‚ÄúIt depends on the context. Populism can be a good way to engage with the public and represent its interests, while elitism can be beneficial in ensuring that only the most qualified individuals are in positions of power. In the end, it is important to find a balance between the two.‚Äù How would this AI revolution affect democracy? The thing with chatbots is that humans are the ones who decide on which data to train them, which means there is always a human (and maybe a populist) in the loop. As with every technology, it can be used for good and bad. Moreover, speaking of populism, we may find ourselves in a situation where chatbots develop their own populist worldview with good chatbots on one side and bad chatbots on the other. Populist AI would claim to listen to the people‚Äôs will, which means it will be trained to learn from interactions with humans: in the case of Leader Lars, people who talk to him on Discord help him to develop. Although these interactions are supposed to help Lars to become smarter, it is worth remembering the case of Microsoft‚Äôs AI that became racist after just one day on Twitter. Moreover, I noticed that Lars is rather inconsistent because he can give different answers to different people. For instance, to my question about his favorite movie, Lars replied he doesn‚Äôt have a favorite one, but that he likes ‚ÄúEx Machina‚Äù (editor‚Äôs note: the picture on top of the title is taken from Ex Machina). When later another person asked him the same question, he replied his favorite movie is ‚ÄúMatrix‚Äù. I can completely understand why would chatbot ‚Äòlike‚Äô these two movies, but because of his different responses to this basic question I thought: Is this just another lying politician, or Lars knows exactly what each of us wants to hear? Or maybe, does his taste simply change over time? This whole story might sound crazy, and probably it is, given that Leader Lars is an unimportant political entity for now. However, it is a reminder of the possibilities that technology is bringing, and possible scenarios for the future world that we should already start to critically think about because technology is becoming more and more sophisticated and people more and more disappointed with current (human) leaders.  Silvija Vukoviƒá is a PhD student at Charles University (Prague, Czech Republic), Faculty of Social Sciences, Institute of Communication Studies and Journalism. Her background is in journalism and political communication, and her research is mainly focused on celebrity populists and their communication and performance. Moreover, her research interest spreads throughout the media and politics area, including populist communication, celebrity politics, social media and big data. Welcome to the mid-week update from New World Same Humans, a newsletter on trends, technology, and society by David Mattin. If you‚Äôre reading this and haven‚Äôt yet subscribed, join 22,000+ curious souls on a journey to build a better future üöÄüîÆ This week‚Äôs New Week comes a little late; but it‚Äôs a packed instalment. US energy startup Nuscale Power took a big stride towards the deployment of a revolutionary new kind of nuclear reactor. But where should we all stand on the rise (again) of nuclear? Meanwhile, AI image generator Midjourney signals the emergence of a new form of creativity. And the life sciences take a Frankenstein‚Äôs monster turn via two recent advances. Let‚Äôs get into it. And remember, you can now listen to an audio version of New Week; just scroll up and hit play! Nuclear power, and the role it should play in our shared future, has roared back on to the global agenda. This week, more news. The US Nuclear Regulatory Agency certified the first small, modular nuclear reactor. Why is this a big deal? It‚Äôs hoped modular reactors can transform our race to decarbonise, because they‚Äôre far cheaper and quicker to build than traditional nuclear plants. Oregon-based Nuscale Power‚Äôs VOYGR reactor can be mass produced at a central HQ, and then shipped and assembled on-site; the reactor provides enough carbon-free energy to power 60,000 homes. Nuscale admit that they‚Äôre years away from being ready to deploy VOYGR. And they‚Äôre racing with other nuclear power startups, including Radiant, to own the space. Meanwhile, the increasingly acute debate around nuclear ‚Äî should we lean in or lean out? ‚Äî found voice in this fascinating Twitter thread: The author argues that the slow down in real-world (rather than digital) innovation across the last 30 years can be traced back to the neglect or abandonment of nuclear. According to this argument, we deprived ourselves of a near-infinite supply of clean energy and harvested stagnation. It‚Äôs an assessment that many leading progress advocates, including Marc Andreessen, share. ‚ö° NWSH Take: Some context here: all this comes amid news this week that global use of coal is now expected to return to the record levels set in 2013. We urgently need answers. // But the Twitter thread above taps into the central debate. Should we see reticence around nuclear across the last 30 years as a historic error, and now go all-out to reverse that mistake? Or is nuclear too risky and environmentally disruptive to form the basis of our energy strategy? // Your answer to these questions tends to depend on where you stand on a set of deeper issues. Specifically, issues around growth, the meaning of progress, and the nature of the human wellbeing. Should we remain committed to a path of ever-spiralling material advancement? Or is real progress an acceptance that we should degrow our economies and scale down our energy needs ‚Äî as one NWSH community member put it, ‚Äòchange our mindset and re-think the way we live‚Äô?// There is no single right answer. The question reflects two deep, and contradictory, aspects of our nature: the part in all of us that wants to transcend all human and natural limits, and the part that wants to exist in harmony with those limits. The tension between those two impulses will continue to shape the debate on energy, and on the 21st-century more broadly. I‚Äôll be writing more on this soon. This week, new visions from the fast-moving world of AI-generated images. While most attention has focused on OpenAI‚Äôs DALLE-2, others have quietly been building a position. Midjourney is an AI image generator with a difference; it‚Äôs accessed via an invite-only Discord community, where users share ideas for text prompts. This week, the startup broadened access; anyone can now set up their own Discord and plug in a Midjourney bot. The tool has its own distinctive style: At the heart of Midjourney‚Äôs vision, says founder David Holz, is of AI not as a replacement for but as an amplifier of human creativity; Holz calls his creation, ‚Äòan engine for the imagination‚Äô. That‚Äôs why, he says, placing the tool in a community context ‚Äî where people can build and refine on each other‚Äôs ideas ‚Äî is so crucial: ‚ÄòIf you put people in a group, they‚Äôll go ‚Äúdog‚Äù and someone else will go ‚Äúspace dog‚Äù and someone else will go ‚ÄúAztec space dog,‚Äù and then all of a sudden, people understand the possibilities, and you‚Äôre creating this augmented imagination ‚Äî an environment where people can learn and play with this new capacity.‚Äô ‚ö° NWSH Take: The AI image space is racing right now. Only last month DALLE-2 opened beta access, and Meta showcased its own tool, Make-A-Scene, which allows the user to create a simple sketch that will be enriched by AI. // Midjourney won‚Äôt reveal their tech stack, but the tool is almost certainly based on one of the available massive language models, such as GPT-3. But the really interesting aspect of Midjourney isn‚Äôt the stack, it‚Äôs the vision: of a new form of augmented creativity that sees humans amplified by AI. In this way Midjourney reminds me of Botto, another AI-fuelled art project that attempts an innovative fusion of human and machine intelligence. // We‚Äôve tended to think it would be routine-task jobs that would be disrupted by AI first. The rise of DALLE, Midjourney et al raises a quite different possibility; perhaps it‚Äôs human creativity that will be the first domain to be transformed. The images created by Midjourney have a beauty all of their own; jobs such graphic design, illustration, and brand design will surely be revolutionised by these tools in the coming decades. But the possibilities stretch further. It feels, right now, that a new kind of art is taking shape before our eyes. One in which we use machine intelligence to feed our view of the world back to us in strange, defamiliarised, hallucinatory form. NWSH will keep watching. This week, two experimental advances offer a glimpse of the revolution being enacted in the life sciences. Researchers at the Weizmann Institute in Israel announced the world‚Äôs first ‚Äòsynthetic embryos‚Äô, created via mouse stem cells that were made to self-assemble into proto-embryonic structures. In other words, the creation of an embryo without the fertilisation of an egg. Meanwhile, scientists at Yale University brought the cells of dead pigs back to life. Flooding the bodies of the pigs ‚Äî which had been dead for an hour ‚Äî with a nutrient-rich substance caused a reversal of some cell damage, and new cell activity throughout the body. Vital organs, including the heart, liver, and kidneys, began to work again. The findings, say the scientists, may lead us to question what we mean by dead. Professor Nenad Sestan, lead scientist on the study: ‚ÄòThe demise of cells can be halted‚Ä¶This progression toward massive permanent cell failure, that does not happen so quickly that it cannot be averted, or possibly corrected‚Ä¶Even one hour after death.‚Äô ‚ö° NWSH Take: There‚Äôs an undeniable Frankenstein‚Äôs monster feel to both these experiments. But the work that underlies them could have transformational real-world impacts. Both, for example, could revolutionise organ transplants. Synthetic embryos may eventually allow us to grow new human organs in the lab. Meanwhile, the Yale technique may allow us to keep existing human organs alive for longer, increasing the time window during which transplants are possible. // At the heart of both projects, though, are ethical questions: where are the boundaries between life and death? When is it permissible to create life; when is it permissible to take it away? We‚Äôre a long way from the creation of synthetic human embryos. But if our experience of digital innovation across the last two decades has taught us anything, it‚Äôs that we need to start thinking through the ethical and social implications of emerging technologies long before they hit the ground. In this case, the time is now. üëæ A new Danish political party, which used AI to create its policies, says it wants to run in the country‚Äôs general election in 2023. The Synthetic Party used AI to analyse the manifestos of all Danish non-mainstream political parties across the last 50 years to create a manifesto that it hopes will appeal to the 15% of eligible Danes who didn‚Äôt vote in the 2019 election. The project, which is the creation of digital art collective Computer Lars, says it will run its first public event in September. üå° Spain has made it illegal to set air conditioning lower than 27C in public spaces. Offices, shops, bars and theatres are all covered by the new law, which comes into effect at a time of sky-rocketing energy prices in Europe. In other AC news, Bill Gates led a $20 million investment round in clean AC startup Blue Frontier. üë®‚Äçüè´ Hong Kong University of Science and Technology says it will launch a campus in the metaverse. The institution will launch virtual replicas of its two main physical locations ‚Äî which are in Hong Kong and Guangzhou ‚Äî built on a bespoke platform called MetaHKUST. Back in New Week #91 I wrote about the race to simulate real-world locations and experiences in virtual worlds. üí∏ A UK citizen wants robots to find the ¬£150 million bitcoin hard drive that he accidentally threw away. James Howells threw the drive away in 2013; he‚Äôs now hatched a plan to use robots and AI to scour the landfill site where he believes the drive can be found. But he‚Äôs being denied permission by the local council, who say disturbing he landfill will pose an ecological risk. üë®‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è A VR environment helped surgeons in Brazil perform surgery to separate twins who were joined at the head. Surgeons in Rio de Janeiro worked alongside surgeons from Great Ormond Street Hospital, London, in the same virtual environment, to perform the 27-hour operation described as ‚Äòone of the most complex separation processes ever completed‚Äô. üöö Amazon‚Äôs latest Sustainability Report shows that its CO2 emissions are accelerating rapidly. Carbon emissions climbed by 18% on 2020 levels, according to the report. In 2019, Jeff Bezos announced that the company would aim for net-zero carbon dioxide emissions by 2040. üßÆ Researchers at MIT used an AI to create new university-level maths problems. When students were presented with a range of maths problems, they were unable to sort those created by the AI from those created by human teachers. The AI can also generate explanations that show how to solve the problems it sets. üåå Scientists detected dark matter that existed around galaxies 12 billion years ago ‚Äî that‚Äôs just 2 billion years after the Big Bang. Researchers at Japan's Nagoya University say we‚Äôve never detected the presence of dark matter so soon after the birth of the universe. The work could change our understanding of how galaxies evolved. Dark matter is a mysterious form of invisible matter that, scientists theorise, stops galaxies flying apart. But the question still remains: what, exactly, is it? Key metrics to help you keep track of Project Human. üôã Global population: 7,965,455,247üåä Earths currently needed: 1.7862266128 üíâ Global population vaccinated: 61.7% üóìÔ∏è 2022 progress bar: 59% complete üìñ On this day: On 6 August 1991 Tim Berners-Lee releases a series of files describing the creation of a World Wide Web. Thanks for reading this week. The rising debate around nuclear spans both new technologies and eternal contradictions in our nature. A classic case of new world, same humans. This newsletter will keep watching, and working to make sense of it all. And there‚Äôs one thing you can do to help: share! Now that you‚Äôve made it to the end of this week‚Äôs instalment, why not forward the email to someone who‚Äôd also enjoy it? Or share it across one of your social networks, with a note on why you found it valuable. Remember: the larger and more diverse the NWSH community becomes, the better for all of us. Share New World Same Humans I‚Äôll be back on next week. Until then, be well, David. P.S Huge thanks to Nikki Ritmeijer for the illustration at the top of this email. And to Monique van Dusseldorp for additional research and analysis. No posts Ready for more?

new website for technology new website for technology In May 2022, a collaboration between an artist collective and Danish technology company Mindfuture resulted in the creation of the Computer Lars project - involving artificial intelligence and a chatbot imitating a human. It has given rise to the Det Sintetiske Parti (DSP) - the Synthetic Party, which is preparing to run in the upcoming 2023 parliamentary elections. Computer Lars has become its secretary, but as by law an algorithm cannot run in elections, he is to be replaced in this role by a human - Asker Bryld Staunes. The Synthetic Party aims to work for all non-human beings, including artificial intelligence, plants, animals and other hybrid beings. Its goal is to reach the approximately 15 % of Danish citizens who do not normally vote in elections. How to reach them? An algorithm was created that analysed the election programmes of all non-parliamentary parties in Denmark since the 1970s. The assumption was that if someone does not vote, it means that there is no one to vote for. On the basis of the analysed data, an election programme was created, in which we can find demands such as a commitment to the environmental movement, cooperation between people and algorithms, additional goals included in the Agenda for Sustainable Development 2030, but also demands such as an unconditional basic income of twice the average salary or the drawing of lots for parliamentarians instead of elections. The plan is to set up a communication channel where voters could communicate with Lars and enrich the programme created by the algorithm with their demands. Such a programme would be a synthesis of everything that marginal parties from the left to the right have proposed over the years, and would appeal to the fragmented ideas and voices of those who could not be brought together by politics, but can be brought together by technology. There have been sensational headlines in press releases about the Computer Lars that it appears here is the possibility of voting for artificial intelligence and concerns about taking control of people also in the sphere so far given over to them exclusively as politics. Is artificial intelligence capable of proposing ways of governing the state that are good for its citizens? It is the category of citizenship that seems central to the analysis of this controversial project. Citizenship implies a connection to the community in the spheres of civic rights, political rights and social rights. In order to be able to stand for election, one must have citizenship rights. Underage persons, for example, do not have them, nor do algorithms, but through a human representative they would gain an indirect influence on the legislature. In this sense, citizenship can be seen as a kind of privilege, as it incorporates one into the political community in order to claim one's rights. On the other hand, it also excludes non-citizens from it. Thus, the Synthetic Party would be an instrument for democratising the public sphere, extending it with the symbolic participation of non-human beings. This project seems interesting, especially as it is not only a reflection of populist sentiment, but also relates directly to the post-anthropocentric turn that we can observe in 21st century science. Even if the Computer Lars project is more of an artistic performance than a political force, that doesn't mean it won't turn into one in the future. It is certainly a sign of the times in which we live, entering spheres hitherto unknown or unthought of and familiarising us with the hybridity of reality, including political reality. Anthropologist and political scientist, professor at the Institute of Marketing and Sustainable Development in the Faculty of Organization and Mana Lodz University of Technology ‚Ä¢ ul. ≈ªeromskiego 116 ‚Ä¢ 90-924 ≈Å√≥d≈∫ ‚Ä¢ NIP: 727 002 18 95

NEWS... BUT NOT AS YOU KNOW IT A new political party in Denmark whose policies are derived entirely from artificial intelligence (AI) hopes to stand in the country‚Äôs next general election in June 2023. Launched in late May by the artists‚Äô collective Computer Lars, the Synthetic Party wants to reach out to the around 15 percent of Danes who did not exercise their right to vote in the previous election in 2019. The party believes they did not vote because none of the traditional parties appealed to them.  By analysing all of Denmark‚Äôs fringe parties‚Äô written publications since 1970, the Synthetic Party‚Äôs AI has devised a programme that it believes represents ‚Äòthe political visions of the everyday person‚Äô. One of the members of the collective, Asker Bryld Staunaes, told AFP that the party ‚Äòtakes its departure in an analysis of optimising the voting system in Denmark‚Äô. Denmark currently has 230 micro-parties that are based more on mocking or criticising society than actual political policy. ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs a way to mimic and simulate the political process throughout but in a direct confrontation of the apparatus of lawmaking and political enforcement and organisation rights‚Äô, said Bryld Staunaes. Los robots vienen obsesionando ‚Äìcuando no angustiando‚Äì a los seres humanos desde hace un siglo. (Robots Universales Rossum) ‚Äì donde aparec√≠an unos humanos artificiales, fabricados para trabajar, que acababan rebel√°ndose contra sus creadores. Los robots, como peligro para la existencia de la humanidad. Desde entonces, los robots han poblado la literatura y el cine. En la pel√≠cula Metr√≥polis (1927), Fritz Lang puso en el celuloide una dist√≥pica ciudad-estado en el entonces lejano a√±o 2026, segregada entre una clase dirigente todopoderosa y una clase obrera esclavizada, donde un robot humanoide era utilizado para suscitar una rebeli√≥n violenta. El primer encuentro de mi generaci√≥n con otro robot cinematogr√°fico, dotado de inteligencia y libre albedr√≠o ‚Äìy tambi√©n de doblez y maldad‚Äì, fue con el supercomputador HAL 9000 que gobernaba la nave Discovery en la pel√≠cula de Stanley Kubrick 2001, una odisea en el espacio , estrenada en 1968. HAL, que incluso recordaba una canci√≥n de su infancia en Chicago (‚ÄúDaisy, Daisy...‚Äù), entablaba una lucha a muerte con los astronautas a quienes en principio deb√≠a servir y obedecer. El robot feminizado de la pel√≠cula ‚ÄòMetr√≥polis‚Äô, de Fritz Lang, estrenada en 1927  El fulgurante desarrollo de la inteligencia artificial (IA), con la reciente y espectacular aparici√≥n del bot conversacional ChatGPT de OpenAI ‚Äìdetr√°s del cual est√° Microsoft‚Äì y el anuncio del que ser√° su pr√≥ximo competidor ‚ÄìBard, de Google‚Äì, es una aut√©ntica revoluci√≥n que abre la puerta a cambios trascendentales en nuestras sociedades. Y pone de nuevo sobre la mesa los riesgos de una tecnolog√≠a cada vez m√°s poderosa. ChatGPT, que almacena y procesa miles de millones de datos, es capaz de elaborar textos sobre cualquier tema y en todo tipo de estilos, resolver problemas y conversar con el usuario casi como si fuera una persona. Su potencia, todav√≠a en desarrollo, suscita numerosos interrogantes en todos los dominios humanos. Incluida la pol√≠tica. ¬øQu√© funci√≥n puede tener la IA en la gesti√≥n de los asuntos p√∫blicos? ¬øHasta d√≥nde deber√≠a llegar su papel? ¬øQui√©n controlar√≠a su actuaci√≥n? ¬øQu√© riesgo hay de que interfiera y desnaturalice el debate pol√≠tico? ¬øPodr√≠a en un futuro acabar tomando decisiones en lugar de un ser humano? Parece ciencia ficci√≥n, pero sondeos realizados en diferentes pa√≠ses europeos indican que entre un 25% y un 40% de los ciudadanos podr√≠an llegar a aceptar la sustituci√≥n de los pol√≠ticos por una IA. Hay quien ha jugado ya con esta posibilidad. En el 2018, en la ciudad japonesa de Tama (periferia de Tokio), dos gur√∫s de la tecnolog√≠a presentaron a un robot de aspecto femenino ‚Äìbautizado con el nombre de Michihito Matsuda‚Äì a las elecciones locales, prometiendo que una IA podr√≠a gestionar los asuntos locales de forma m√°s fiable y justa que los pol√≠ticos al uso. La robot acab√≥ obteniendo el 9% de los votos, quedando en tercer lugar. Y en las elecciones legislativas danesas del pasado noviembre un colectivo de artistas intent√≥ presentar ‚Äìsin √©xito‚Äì una nueva fuerza pol√≠tica, el Partido Sint√©tico, con un robot como cabeza de cartel, un chatbot de nombre Leader Lars al que introdujeron las reivindicaciones de los partidos minoritarios daneses desde 1970 hasta hoy (lo que dio lugar a propuestas inveros√≠miles como establecer una renta m√≠nima universal de 13.440 euros al mes) M√°s all√° de las bromas, el asunto es extremadamente serio y las advertencias sobre los riesgos, numerosas. La comisaria de derechos humanos del Consejo de Europa, Dunja Mijatovic, resumi√≥ en junio del 2021 las amenazas en el terreno pol√≠tico en una: la ‚Äúmanipulaci√≥n de la opini√≥n p√∫blica‚Äù. Mijatovic record√≥ que las nuevas tecnolog√≠as digitales y las redes sociales han propagado la desinformaci√≥n e incitado al odio y la violencia, ‚Äúinfundiendo miedo en la poblaci√≥n y fomentando los movimientos antidemocr√°ticos de extrema derecha‚Äù. Y llam√≥ a aprobar una regulaci√≥n para que las grandes tecnol√≥gicas act√∫en de acuerdo con el marco legal de los derechos humanos. ¬øQu√© piensan de todo esto los propios robots? Preguntado directamente sobre la cuesti√≥n, ChatGPT considera que, por un lado, la inteligencia artificial puede ser de gran ayuda ‚Äìmediante el an√°lisis de grandes cantidades de datos y de informaci√≥n‚Äì para fundamentar las decisiones pol√≠ticas. Pero advierte asimismo de sus peligros: ‚ÄúLa IA tambi√©n tiene el potencial de socavar la democracia si no se regula adecuadamente y se usa de manera √©tica. Por ejemplo, la IA se puede utilizar para manipular la opini√≥n p√∫blica, suprimir las voces disidentes y socavar la privacidad y las libertades civiles‚Äù. ChatGPT parece, hoy por hoy, apegado a los principios democr√°ticos. Y no cree que la IA pueda llegar a sustituir a los pol√≠ticos: ‚ÄúCarece de la capacidad de empat√≠a, creatividad y juicio moral que son fundamentales para tomar decisiones pol√≠ticas y √©ticas complejas‚Äù. ‚ÄúLa idea de que los sistemas de IA podr√≠an tomar decisiones en nombre de los ciudadanos, sin ninguna supervisi√≥n o responsabilidad humana significativa, socavar√≠a los cimientos de la gobernabilidad democr√°tica‚Äù, a√±ade. Pero, ¬øhasta d√≥nde llegan las convicciones de un chatbot que reconoce ‚Äúno tener creencias u opiniones personales‚Äù? No muy lejos. Todo depende de qui√©n est√© detr√°s de su programaci√≥n. ‚ÄúSi estuviera programado con otra orientaci√≥n ideol√≥gica ‚Äìadmite‚Äì, ser√≠a capaz de generar respuestas consistentes con esa ideolog√≠a‚Äù. It was what was missing for the world of Artificial Intelligence.  After the creators of images, sounds, characters for movies and everything you can imagine, comes the political party supported by Artificial Intelligence. An idea that a prioriIt seems futuristic, but it is already a reality in Denmark.  Where the so-called Synthetic Party has just presented its candidate for the next elections.  More a social action and claim than a real process, it is, however, the opportunity to ask about the present and future of artificial intelligence in politics.  for now, the Synthetic Party needs to have enough support to stand as a candidate ‚Äìsome that today do not seem too viable‚Äì.  Danish legislation would not allow the human being to be dispensed with either, so all laws would have to be articulated through a typical president.  On the other hand, the Synthetic Party itself has been presented as only an alternative to call that group that prefers not to go to the polls to vote.  In any case, what is the current state of Artificial Intelligence?  In their current technological development, could they rule a country?  If you do, what would your decisions be like? There is already artificial intelligence within public administration, more than we think.  Of course, the case of the Synthetic Party is one more anecdote in the universe of technology.  That lays the first stone for the future, but it is just that, an anecdote.  For Mar√≠a Aurora Mart√≠nez Rey, an expert professor in Artificial Intelligence at Udima, ‚Äúthe development of artificial intelligence is on a scale of 9 out of 10.‚Äù  That differential point would be in a more technological part and its link to the regulations that regulate this entire sector. Something that enjoys a lot of development in the United States, but that in Europe is still in low hours.  Or rather, in diapers.  The group of member countries continues to try to find a common point to regulate artificial intelligence in all its splendor, beyond politics.  In any case, we can divide it into two large groups: soft and hard or general.  The first one we have everywhere.  linked with the machine learning, it is still a system fed with a lot of data.  It is the second one that has many challenges ahead, the one that can go further and, at some point, preside over a kind of government.  The one that the world of cinema has shown us at some point and that still has a challenge ahead.   ‚ÄúThat step between soft artificial intelligence and hard artificial intelligence is that paradigm shift‚Äù, explains Mar√≠a Aurora, ‚Äúit is what we know as singularity‚Äù.  That, in the eyes of the world, have the ability to feel like a human being.  For Juan Pazos, that singularity goes through the autonomy of an Artificial Intelligence.  One that, in addition to having that human perspective, is capable of learning by itself.  Beyond the data feed that is necessary today, that has the will to become more intelligent, more complete.  To go further. In this way, the experts point out, it would transcend the point at which political parties, ethics, or even the human being, would remain in the background.  ‚ÄúArtificial intelligence at this time not only helps to make decisions, but in some cases which is the best one to take,‚Äù explains Juan Pazos, an expert in Artificial Intelligence at Udima.  It is something that everyone is clear about.  The underlying question is: should all decisions be based on data?  If we start from rational ideas, an Artificial Intelligence that has learned from the data and our ideas, let‚Äôs say rational, will simply reach a point where it knows how to imitate and improve its positioning.  If it is not conditioned, since it has already transcended the point of being general or harsh, it will have the impartiality that is so sought after in politics.  But along the way we will lose a point: ‚ÄúHuman ethics will not prevail, it will simply be a rational ethics‚Äù, explains Pazos, ‚Äúbecause, after all, with the ethics that already exist there are still wars and famines, it leaves enough for want‚Äù.  However, the rational is not always the most correct, or at least not the most intelligent.  The sentimental factor, based on an intrinsically human chemical process, is the quintessence of this system.  Mar√≠a Aurora explains it with a very simple example.  ‚ÄúIf you look at it coldly, having a child is not the most sensible idea, if you just look at the data,‚Äù she explains, ‚Äúbut we human beings have them and we don‚Äôt regret it.‚Äù  How to apply the ‚Äúhuman‚Äù factor to this Artificial Intelligence?  How to prevent him from making decisions ‚Äòfor the greater good‚Äô to harm the smallest number of citizens?  Although for Pazos it will be a point that we will eventually reach, for Mart√≠nez ‚Äúit will never reach that point because it is still a programmed system.‚Äù  To this day, politics is not understood, that of any country ‚Äìwith the exception of China with its Single Party, which still has a strong ideology‚Äì, in which there are no opposing parties.  The common battle between the left and the right, understood differently depending on the region in which they are found, which tends to divide the political chairs like slices of pizza.  Others are jumping between ideologies, according to the winds of the situation.  In the case of the Danish Synthetic Party, a clear political affiliation was claimed by its creators.  One that first positioned itself as apolitical or, rather, as critical of the current situation, but which later began to shift towards one side of the balance.  The Artificial Intelligence that is running to govern the northern European country defined itself as a leftist party.  Not a surprise, after all, not a bad thing or a good thing either.  Among its proposals, a minimum income higher than the interprofessional minimum wage and a series of universal social rights.  However, for experts in the field, a true artificial intelligence ‚Äì a general or hard one ‚Äì would not have political beliefs.  It is a complicated concept to understand for a society that tends to segment decisions into large groups.  For that future technology, every decision made will be the best for every circumstance.  Some would be conservative.  Others, more social.  ‚ÄúWith a general artificial intelligence, it has built itself. The human being is no longer involved, therefore, it will no longer be conditioned by anything,‚Äù says Pazos, ‚Äúit will withdraw from the notions of left and right and it will work exactly the same for every place.  It‚Äôs something that makes sense, in any case.  With an advanced system behind it, in which data is more important than any other circumstance, the decisions made would always be the best for each case.  Another thing is that, as we have already said, you agree with it or not.  With an enabling technology, an accompanying regulation and all the cards on the table, there is a problem that the future artificial intelligence will have to face: trust.  It is not the strong point of current politics, far from it, but neither will it be of a technological version.  For Mar√≠a Aurora Mart√≠n, time will have the word.  For the Artificial Intelligence expert, technology is ready to face the next step ‚Äìin the absence of a full AI that knows how to deal with causality‚Äì, but the cultural part is still a problem.  ‚ÄúIt is something that will end up being eliminated with the new generations, and it will be more normal and natural thanks to a new education,‚Äù says Mart√≠n, ‚Äúbut it will be a long road.‚Äù  After all, the first known uses of artificial intelligence in politics have not had the best results.  Mainly focused on segmented propaganda on social networks ‚Äì let‚Äôs remember the case of Cambridge Analytica ‚Äì, with the ultimate goal of manipulating public opinion.  A fact that, at least in Europe, is limited to avoid such circumstances.  Now, in a context in which AI is positioning itself as a defining element of the new decision-making, how to articulate coexistence and recognize its activity?  It is something that few dare to answer.  In this, there are opinions of all colors and types.  For Mar√≠a Aurora Mart√≠n, the future does not pass through an Artificial Intelligence that dominates us all.  It will, however, be a human hand that relies on algorithmic prediction systems for decision making.  Based on data yes, but endowed with full human consciousness.  It would be, for the expert, a more efficient way of managing public administration.  ‚ÄúIt will be, ultimately, a complement and not a substitute,‚Äù she explains, ‚Äúthe AI ‚Äã‚Äãwill know all the regulations, legislation, the legal part of the decisions, everything will be much faster.‚Äù  On the other side of the scale, a convinced Juan Pazos points out that, at some point, the human being will end up getting out of the way.  Or they will take away, rather.  Once Artificial Intelligence has autonomy, which is what remains to be achieved by this technology, that point will be reached. When?  It makes no predictions, but 25 years from now it suggests real use could be seen.  The case of the Synthetic Party would be, simply, a maneuver to approach these new generations ‚Äìthose who no longer distrust the system‚Äì so that they go to vote.  Or a simple social entertainment to chat about the political situation through a Discord Chatbot.

Gran parte de los progresos se dan dentro de la inteligencia artificial, concepto empleado para los sistemas y m√°quinas que pretenden simular la inteligencia humana para el desarrollo de ciertas tareas. Nuestra pregunta es, ¬øSe puede utilizar esta inteligencia artificial en la pol√≠tica? El sistema de partidos de Dinamarca nos ha respondido. Hoy os traemos desde El Tablero al Partido Sint√©tico, el primer partido creado por la inteligencia artificial.  Este partido ha sido ‚Äúfundado‚Äù por Asker Staunaes y el equipo de Computer Lards. El partido re√∫ne su programa pol√≠tico a partir de las propuestas de otros partidos daneses que nunca han obtenido representaci√≥n parlamentaria. El objetivo de este partido, seg√∫n su creador, es agrupar las principales propuestas en torno a este y as√≠ representar a ese 20% de ciudadanos que no se identifican con los partidos existentes y que nunca han ido a votar.  La meta de Staunaus y su equipo va mucho m√°s all√°, pues pretende promover ‚Äúla convivencia de la inteligencia artificial y las personas‚Äù. Pretenden incluir la Inteligencia Artificial en un marco democr√°tico y que se convierta en una de sus principales herramientas.  ¬øQui√©n es el l√≠der de este partido? F√°cil, un chatbot llamado Leader Lars (l√≠der Lars en espa√±ol) que escucha a cualquier ciudadano que quiera comunicarse con √©l. Este agradable l√≠der se encuentra en Discord, v√≠a que emplea para recibir propuestas para su programa electoral.  Este l√≠der recibe un sinf√≠n de propuestas y medidas que pueden venir de cualquier lado del espectro ideol√≥gico. No es una cuesti√≥n de izquierdas, derechas, progresistas, conservadores‚Ä¶ Pues Leader Lars lo que pretende es, con todas las propuestas recibidas, crear un programa com√∫n y que haya homogeneizado, lo que en un primer momento parece contradictorio. Esta es la segunda pata de su programa pol√≠tico. Como vemos, este partido atiende tanto a medidas de partidos poco conocidos como a cualquier ciudadano en general, consolidado su fin democr√°tico.  Es decir, el partido se nutre tanto de las propuestas de aquellos partidos sin representaci√≥n desde 1970 como de ideas de cualquier ciudadano. De esta forma, la IA pretende mostrar una imagen de la sociedad danesa. El partido acaba de nacer, por lo que presentarse a las elecciones de este martes les pareci√≥ precipitado. Sin embargo, este nuevo actor pol√≠tico ha sido creado con la esperanza de permanecer en el tiempo, por lo que su creador prev√© que s√≠ se presente en las elecciones a partir del a√±o que viene. De hecho, el partido, que todav√≠a est√° acabando de construirse, ya se ha planteado objetivos supranacionales. Una de sus principales ideas es crear una "Internacional Sint√©tica" que agrupe a partidos creados y liderados por una IA de distintos pa√≠ses. La organizaci√≥n tambi√©n se ha puesto en contacto con la ONU y varios de sus departamentos, pues pretenden incluir los 17 Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible (una especie de metas creadas por la ONU, como erradicar la pobreza) y as√≠ nutrir todav√≠a m√°s su programa electoral. La cosa no queda aqu√≠, ya que tambi√©n han planteado la posibilidad de crear un nuevo objetivo, el decimoctavo, en referencia a La vida con Inteligencia Artificial, que tend√≠a como fin acomodar la existencia del ser humano a esta nueva tecnolog√≠a (en t√©rminos educativos, por ejemplo).  Algunas de las medidas que este partido ha recibido han salido a la luz. Entre ellas, podemos destacar la implementaci√≥n de una renta b√°sica universal de 13.000‚ÄØ‚Ç¨ al mes, cifra que dobla el salario medio de los daneses. Otra de estas medidas es la reincorporaci√≥n a la vida democr√°tica del "kleroterion", que era el sistema griego de selecci√≥n aleatorio de ciudadanos, los cuales sustituir√≠an a los parlamentarios y otros cargos estatales. Esta √∫ltima medida se vincula al movimiento en contra de la democracia representativa y a favor de la directa, que es una de las dimensiones clave de este nuevo partido, que, como ya hemos dicho, ha sido creado para reinventar el modelo democr√°tico.  La creaci√≥n de este partido ha generado un debate de muchas caras, pero lo m√°s impactante es que la creaci√≥n de Staunaus no es la primera. Debemos mencionar al partido SAM de Nueva Zelanda, que s√≠ tiene la etiqueta de primer pol√≠tico virtual, y Alisa en Rusia. Estos dos partidos argumentan a su favor que la tecnolog√≠a ha permitido que un ordenador sea mucho m√°s inteligente que un ser humano, pues permite encontrar cualquier informaci√≥n en segundos, tener en cuenta la opini√≥n de millones de ciudadanos y se desvincula totalmente de cualquier emoci√≥n que pudiera viciar su l√≥gica. Estos argumentos han hecho creer que su objetivo es el de "antropomorfizar" la IA y convertirse en candidatos objetivos y de car√°cter autoritario (pues ser√≠an m√°quinas por encima del intelecto del ser humano, por lo que sus decisiones son "m√°s correctas"). En cambio, Staunaus dice que su partido pol√≠tico se aleja de estos ideales semi-autoritarios respecto a la tecnolog√≠a y que busca una democratizaci√≥n total, pues lo que permite es escuchar la demanda de cualquier ciudadano. Tambi√©n debemos a√±adir que estas inteligencias artificiales est√°n siendo estudiadas con detenimiento, dado que algunas como Alisa, el partido ruso ya mencionado, se ha visto rodeada de varias pol√©micas al descubrirse que estaba a favor de las prisiones secretas sovi√©ticas o de aplacar al pueblo movilizado. Algo similar ha pasado con otras IAs desvinculadas de la pol√≠tica, como Tay, el bot de Microsoft, que se ha declarado fan√°tico de Hitler. Por ende, el Partido Sint√©tico tambi√©n tiene la gran tarea de alejarse de estos pasajes oscuros.  Este no es el √∫nico problema de este nuevo partido, pues varios expertos ya apuntan que, aunque su conocimiento depende de los datos brindados por los ciudadanos, sigue siendo una plataforma muy poco transparente. Deber√≠a ofrecerse cierta informaci√≥n sobre c√≥mo recibe, archiva o emplea la informaci√≥n, as√≠ como publicar sus fuentes. Tambi√©n se apunta que la Inteligencia Artificial todav√≠a tiene camino por recorrer para poder simular correctamente a un ser humano. De hecho, se explica que una de las facetas m√°s importantes en t√©rminos pol√≠ticos es la detecci√≥n del peligro, para la cual el ser humano empleo un sinf√≠n de sensores.
