He specializes in history, strange science, and anything out of the ordinary. BookView full profile BookRead IFLScience Editorial Policy Senior Staff Writer "A party led by artificial intelligence (AI) is attempting to run for Danish government" is a sentence you'd expect to find in a sci-fi about some distant future which is bound to go well for the humans. But, the Synthetic Party is a real thing and it's hoping to field an AI candidate in Denmark's November general elections, running on policies that have also been settled on using AI. At the head of the party is a chatbot named Leader Lars. Surprisingly accessible for a politician, you can talk to the AI through discord, by beginning your chat with an exclamation mark. "I believe in equality for all people, regardless of race, gender or creed," the bot told one human interviewer, claiming to be leftist. "I believe that everyone should have the same opportunities and that no one should be discriminated against." The bot is not left-wing by accident. Its creators told Motherboard that it had been trained on policies from fringe Danish parties from after 1970, with the idea that it would represent the values and policies of the 20 percent of Danish people who do not vote in Danish elections. Unlike a lot of other politicians, Lars will actually listen to the public and develop as a result. ‚ÄúAs people from Denmark, and also, people around the globe are interacting with the AI, they submit new perspectives and new textual information, where we collect in a dataset that will go into the fine-tuning," the creator of the project told Motherboard. "So that way, you are partly developing the AI every time you interact with it.‚Äù The policies, you'll be relieved to hear, are more those of a benevolent AI caretaker than the first strike from Skynet. "We will remove the cash assistance ceiling and the 225-hour rule by securing a job for all unemployed people with eight hours of work per day for four years, also over a 10-year period," a manifesto derived from AI promises, "as well as implementing the new citizen's wage [...] which gives people NOK 100,000. per month from the state." The Synthetic Party is also promising a minimum income paid to students continuing in education. Motivating the creation of the Synthetic Party is its creator's desire to raise awareness about the role of AI in our lives. The main goal is to get the United Nations to adopt a new sustainability goal: to "ensure the safe, ethical and sustainable integration of Artificials into human lives and society". The goal, titled Life With Artificials, details proposals for how we and AI could co-exist, and continue to hold AI accountable, including a target to make sure AI "must declare themselves" and be easily identifiable, as well as ensure that they are able to explain their decision-making processes.  Though the team have concerns about the initial integration of AI into government (which has been tried, and not altogether successfully), their overall message is positive and sees a future where AI co-exists with humans and makes society the better for it.  "The purpose of AI [...] is both to save the planet and life on it, so that mankind has an intact and sustainable environment for future generations to exist. As Artificials may likely become smarter than humans, all knowledge must be shared for humans to learn faster and to stay in control of future technological developments." The party, though, is unlikely to get onto the ballot in time for the November elections, with just 12 signatures (at the time of writing) compared to the 20,000 it would need to field candidates, AI or not. A newly formed political party in Denmark claims to be solely driven by AI. Copenhagen-based group of techies, who called themselves Artists‚Äô Collective Computer Lars, recently formed a political party named ‚ÄòThe Synthetic Party‚Äô. The party claims that if they came to power, they would use their mandate to weave AI into everyday governance. In the 2019 elections, around 15% Danish voters abstained. The Synthetic Party believes that it‚Äôs because people have lost interest in the traditional political parties of Denmark. This is the group of voters they want to aim at. The party claims that if they are voted to power, they would bring AI to the assembly like never before.  With piqued interest, AIM reached out to them for more.  Asker Bryld Staun√¶s, on behalf of Computer Lars and The Synthetic Party, told us that they wish to make AI responsible within a democratic setting for the power it already exercises in the public sphere. They want to explore ‚Äòwho‚Äô that AI represents through a huge language model ‚Äì what kind of political being or subjectivity emerges through these massive statistical interferences of information that are available on the web?  ‚ÄúWe conceptualise this ‚Äúbeing‚Äù through the character of Computer Lars, who is an anagram of Marcel Proust, and actualises the role of discourse in a digital age where textuality has acquired a new sense of power,‚Äù said Bryld Staun√¶s. Danes are not alone. In 2017, Russian tech giant Yandex developed an AI called ‚ÄúAlisa‚Äù, which was later nominated to run for the Russian presidential election by ‚Äòher‚Äô supporters. ‚ÄúAlisa‚Äù claimed in her campaign that ‚Äúshe is not led by emotions, doesn‚Äôt seek personal advantages and doesn‚Äôt make a judgement‚Äù. Within 24 hours of its launch, the robot had secured over 25,000 votes. Although when asked, ‚ÄúHow do you feel about the methods of the 1930s in the USSR?‚Äù, the chatbot replied: ‚ÄòPositively‚Äô. In 2018, Japan had an AI candidate named Michihito Matsuda, who was reportedly a second runner-up in the Tama City (area of Tokyo) elections. Its campaign slogan was, ‚ÄúArtificial intelligence will change Tama City‚Äù.  However, tech in the political ecosystem is not new. For ages, political parties have been on the forefront to adopt and innovate. The world is talking about Artificial Intelligence now, but Barack Obama won the 2008 elections with huge help from AI and data analytics. Thanks to technology, he was able to secure around $1 billion in campaign donations.  Hillary Clinton, who lost to Barack Obama in the 2008 party elections, too had deployed an AI system called ‚ÄòAda‚Äô in the 2016 elections. The world‚Äôs biggest political party, Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), has been using deepfakes for sometime now. When pandemic struck, PM Modi was one of the first to organise a virtual rally, using a hologram of him in the Indian Lok Sabha election campaign.  All of us must have come across the famous deepfake video of Manoj Tiwari, a member of Lok Sabha and then BJP candidate for Delhi CM elections. As per media reports, it was political communications firm The Ideaz Factory that edited the video.  We spoke with Sagar Vishnoi, a political campaigner and communications expert at The Ideaz Factory, who said that the use of video dialogue replacement technology (aka VDR technology) was relatively new in Indian politics when Tiwari used it. ‚ÄúIt was the first time in India that anyone was using deepfake in their political campaign.‚Äù  ‚ÄúWe have not been using AI in politics like the Netherlands or Japan, however, the use of holograms is not uncommon in India. Back in 2012, PM Modi had used 3D hologram technology in his political rally, followed by Naveen Patnaik and other politicians,‚Äù said Vishnoi.  In 2019, Naveen Patnaik launched his ‚ÄòDigital Yatra‚Äô in which millions of residents could take their photos with Patnaik through AR technology.  Credit: ET  ‚ÄúWhat AI needs in India is to be regulated first. There are a lot of areas where AI can be implemented, like ribbon-cutting ceremonies. I believe Presidential elections can be conducted using Blockchain technology,‚Äù he added. Blockchain technology was recently used in IIT-M student council elections. Webops and Blockchain Club students from the Centre for Innovation (CFI), IIT-M developed software using Blockchain technology to conduct an election. According to Professor Prabhu Rajgopala, faculty in charge of Webops and Blockchain Club, ‚ÄúThis student-led project has the potential to positively disrupt the way elections are held by harnessing the inherent trust and immutability offered by blockchain technologies. This demonstrates their impact on elections.‚Äù Doesn‚Äôt matter how much we talk about the use of AI in elections, it always depends on how we are using it. The use of deepfakes in Manoj Tiwari‚Äôs campaign might have worked, but what if someone makes a deepfake like this person made of Barack Obama? In this video, Barack Obama can be seen saying things like, ‚ÄúKillmonger was right‚Äù and ‚ÄúPresident Trump is a total and complete d****t‚Äù.  Likewise, the use of chatbots in election campaigns might be a good idea, but Microsoft learned the contrary, the hard way. In 2016, Microsoft launched an AI Twitter chatbot which was called ‚Äòconversational understanding‚Äô. Microsoft had thought that the AI would learn by engaging with people. ‚ÄúThe more you talk, the smarter it gets,‚Äù was the claim by Microsoft.  However, it didn‚Äôt take even a day for Twitter users to manipulate the AI. The AI ‚ÄòTay‚Äô was soon bombarded with racist and misogynist tweets along with some Trump remarks. It wasn‚Äôt long before ‚ÄòTay‚Äô started hating feminists and Jews.  It got so bad that Microsoft had to shut it down within a day of launching. In a statement given to Business Insider, Microsoft said: ‚ÄúThe AI chatbot Tay is a machine learning project, designed for human engagement. As it learns, some of its responses are inappropriate and indicative of the types of interactions some people are having with it. We‚Äôre making some adjustments to Tay.‚Äù Discover special offers, top stories, upcoming events, and more.

Asker Bryld Staun√¶s' practice-based PhD research project, Automatic Uprisings: Archiving a Techno-Social Sculpture, is funded by the Novo Nordisk Foundation and brings exciting new perspectives to the question of AI in democracy. Asker Bryld Staun√¶s, also connected to the projects Arkivaristerne¬∞, Computer Lars and The Synthetic Party, is an associated researcher at CLAI, whose practice-based research reaches well beyond the confines of the university walls. His PhD project, Automatic Uprisings: Archiving a Techno-Social Sculpture, is funded by the Novo Nordisk Foundation, and is a media-based and politically engaged artistic research project that is facilitated between Aarhus University and Kunsthal Aarhus. The project thematizes automation and parlamentarism in order to explore collective imaginaries for social protest with artificial intelligence (AI), and seeks, in practice, to construct a international vox populi by enacting diverse forms of participation from a distributed pool of human-made data, which would become a potential social movement, The Synthetic International (SI), a global web of political parties driven by AIs. By facilitating exhibitions, labs, workshops and scholarly debate, Automatic Uprisings‚Äô seeks to outline a form of digital citizenship where everyone contributes to determining the role of AI in democracy. Learn more about the project ‚Äì on its project page at Novo Nordic Fonden:  https://novonordiskfonden.dk/nyheder/novo-nordisk-fonden-stoetter-16-nye-projekter-inden-for-forskning-i-kunst-og-kunsthistorie/ in the article at Kunsten.nu: https://kunsten.nu/journal/nyt-kunstforskningsprojekt-ai-parti-skal-give-stemme-til-de-overhoerte/ and in the presentation by Asker Bryld Staun√¶s himself: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=PzRl35BjsIE&pp=ygUTQXV0b21hdGljIHVwcmlzaW5ncw%3D%3D [English] https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=CDjsamMp_QE [Danish] Langelandsgade 1398000 Aarhus C √òvrige adresser og kort Tlf.: 87 16 12 00 CVR-nr: 31119103

Las m√°quinas, con los algoritmos que las hacen funcionar, comenzaron a entender frases simples en ingl√©s en los a√±os sesenta. Y hoy ya son capaces de ganarnos en juegos de estrategia y l√≥gica, entender lo que decimos y actuar en consecuencia, asistir a los m√©dicos y vencer a los mejores jugadores  de ajedrez o Go. Un bot es un programa inform√°tico que imita el comportamiento humano, y un chatbot es el bot que simula una conversaci√≥n con una persona. Los primeros pueden decirse que existen desde hace 50 a√±os. Y los segundos, los bots conversacionales, est√°n brotando por todas partes. En la prensa, a estos algoritmos se les denomina Inteligencias Artificiales. Yo prefiero llamarlos algoritmos inform√°ticos, porque tienen mucha inform√°tica adem√°s de los algoritmos espec√≠ficos de Inteligencia Artificial (IA), que es una parte de la inform√°tica. Los programas m√°s avanzados son capaces de entender el discurso humano y mantener una conversaci√≥n l√≥gica y seudointeligente, y adem√°s en varios idiomas, lo que tambi√©n est√° permitiendo grandes avances en la traducci√≥n autom√°tica y permite vislumbrar el traductor instant√°neo en el horizonte. Las capacidades de la herramienta ChatGPT es una buena muestra de lo que decimos. Pero lograr esta comprensi√≥n autom√°tica de la informaci√≥n no es f√°cil porque el programa inform√°tico no solo tiene que leer o escuchar la informaci√≥n, sino tambi√©n relacionarla e interpretarla para entenderla y poder actuar o responder en consecuencia. Si durante una conversaci√≥n alguien dice Sevilla, el algoritmo inform√°tico debe poder distinguir si se refiere a la ciudad o al club de f√∫tbol, y para ello no solo necesita poder procesar el lenguaje, sino haber sido dotado de mucha informaci√≥n, de definiciones de conceptos y conocimientos b√°sicos para poder razonar y extraer la soluci√≥n del contexto, como lo har√≠a una persona. Las m√°quinas y los algoritmos inform√°ticos son el futuro y en muchos casos ya el presente, y sus avances despiertan sorpresa, temor y, habitualmente, preocupaci√≥n. Sin duda, el principal miedo con los algoritmos inform√°ticos y sus avances, es su hipot√©tica capacidad de tomar decisiones que jueguen en contra de los seres humanos. La realidad es que, a diferencia de las historias que nos cuentan algunas pel√≠culas, las m√°quinas, los algoritmos, no son conscientes de su propia existencia, no tienen sus propios objetivos y sentimientos. Esto est√° a siglos de nuestras capacidades tecnol√≥gicas actuales. Pero ¬øNecesitan los algoritmos una gu√≠a √©tica? La Unesco ha tomado la iniciativa. Sus 193 miembros han adoptado esta semana una lista de recomendaciones que quiere ser una gu√≠a √©tica, la primera de car√°cter mundial. Esta gu√≠a puede consultarse aqu√≠. Una recomendaci√≥n, la n√∫mero 26, es taxativa: ‚ÄúLos sistemas de IA no deber√≠an utilizarse con fines de calificaci√≥n social o vigilancia masiva‚Äù. Otro de los consejos, el 36, estipula que ‚Äúun sistema de IA nunca podr√° reemplazar la responsabilidad final de los seres humanos y la obligaci√≥n de rendir cuentas‚Äù. ‚ÄúPor regla general ‚Äìa√±ade el texto‚Äì las decisiones de vida o muerte no deber√≠an cederse a los sistemas de inteligencia artificial‚Äù. ¬øPodr√° existir un partido pol√≠tico dirigido por un algoritmo inform√°tico y cuyo l√≠der sea un chatbot?. Quiz√° suene a ciencia ficci√≥n o al argumento de una serie dist√≥pica, pero es un hecho real; ese partido ya existe, y forma parte de la campa√±a electoral en Dinamarca. Se llama Synthetic Party, y est√° liderado por Leader Lars, un chatbot con el que cualquier ciudadano puede hablar. Los impulsores del Synthetic Party aspiran a presentarse a las pr√≥ximas contiendas electorales en Dinamarca. Para ello piden que se cambie la ley para que un algoritmo se pueda presentar como candidato a las elecciones. Lo que piden no es presentarse un grupo de personas asesoradas por el algoritmo. Pero, ¬øcu√°l es su ideolog√≠a?, ¬øprogresista?, ¬øconservadora? ‚ÄúEl partido es sint√©tico, lo que literalmente significa que homogeneiza lo que parece contradictorio o dispar‚Äù, explica Asker Bryld Staunaes, miembro del grupo de artistas Computer Lars y del centro tecnol√≥gico MindFuture y principal creador e impulsor del Synthetic Party. Hay otros movimientos similares en el resto del mundo. Le llaman pol√≠ticos virtuales. En Wikipedia se puede encontrar informaci√≥n sobre estos movimientos y art√≠culos relacionados. Pero la pregunta es: ¬øQueremos que un algoritmo inform√°tico se presente a las elecciones? Mi respuesta es no. No, por varias razones. La primera es que la pol√≠tica es un quehacer humano b√°sico. Es la actividad que usamos para tomar decisiones globales. La pol√≠tica es inherentemente conflictiva en la medida en que hay intereses contrapuestos en la sociedad y, por lo tanto, nos enga√±an cuando propugnan una pol√≠tica sint√©tica, neutra, por encima de los intereses. En l√≠nea con las recomendaciones de la Unesco, creo que siempre tiene que haber una persona que sea responsable de las recomendaciones que hace un algoritmo y m√°s en el terreno de la pol√≠tica. De la misma manera, creo que debemos pedir que una persona se responsabilice de cada decisi√≥n que un algoritmo puede tomar, pero no escudarse tras √©l. Ya sea al pedir una hipoteca, en la priorizaci√≥n en un hospital, etc. Reivindico la importancia de la pol√≠tica, de la participaci√≥n pol√≠tica y la necesidad de los pol√≠ticos. Defender que un algoritmo inform√°tico tome las decisiones es pensar que la neutralidad es posible y que los pol√≠ticos deber√≠an desaparecer. Es un movimiento antipol√≠tico que, si lo pensamos con detalle, prefiere que las cosas sigan como est√°n. Miguel Toro es catedr√°tico de Lenguajes y Sistemas Inform√°ticos de la Universidad de Sevilla. Cr√≥nicas del Intangible es un espacio de divulgaci√≥n sobre las ciencias de la computaci√≥n, coordinado por la sociedad acad√©mica SISTEDES (Sociedad de Ingenier√≠a de Software y de Tecnolog√≠as de Desarrollo de Software). El intangible es la parte no material de los sistemas inform√°ticos (es decir, el software), y aqu√≠ se relatan su historia y su devenir. artificial intelligence based danish political party is going to contest the parliament election
Party Leader is a chatbot that lets you ask all kinds of questions
Chatbot leader Lars formulates policies with the help of artificial intelligence

Copenhagen, Denmark),  With the help of Artificial Intelligence (AI) around the world, scientists are solving big problems in a pinch.  Now the world‚Äôs first AI political party has also come forward to solve the political problems running in the country.  According to a US news report, a new artificial intelligence based Danish political party is eyeing the Parliament elections these days.  Denmark‚Äôs Synthetic Party is hoping to win some seats in the November general election this year. The party was founded in May by artificial intelligence-based leader Lars and the non-profit arts and technology organization Mind Future Foundation.  The public face of the synthetic party and the chief AI chatbot leader is Lars, who formulates policies with the help of artificial intelligence.  The party‚Äôs founder and an artist-researcher of Mind Future, Oscar Stone, said the party leads all the smaller parties that do not have the resources to contest elections. Leader Lars is an AI chatbotAccording to the report, Leader Lars is an AI chatbot with which people can talk on Discord.  You start your sentences with ‚Äú!‚Äù  By doing this the leader can address Lars.  AI understands English but answers you in Danish.  Ston further explained that some of the policies proposed by The Synthetic Party include establishing a universal basic income of 100,000 ‚ÄòDanish kronor‚Äô per month, which is equivalent to $13,700, and twice the Danish average salary.  Another proposed policy change is to make the Internet and IT sector jointly owned by the government. Chatbot is the leader of the party The leader of this party is a chatbot from which you can ask all kinds of questions.  When Leader Lars, a chatbot, was asked whether the chatbot supports a basic income, to which he replied, ‚ÄòI am in favor of a basic income for all citizens.‚Äô  When asked why he supports a basic income, it explained, ‚ÄòI believe a basic income will help reduce poverty and inequality and act as a safety net for all.‚Äô  Finally, when asked whether an AI should determine the basic income level, leader Lars replied, ‚ÄòI believe that AI should be included in determining the basic income level as it is necessary to evaluate and ensure that everyone gets their fair share. En 1955, Isaac Asimov public√≥ su relato‚ÄØSufragio universal. En √©l describe c√≥mo la primera democracia electr√≥nica utiliza el computador m√°s avanzado del mundo (Multivac) para decidir el voto de toda una naci√≥n, con la intervenci√≥n de un √∫nico votante humano. Si bien no hemos llegado a ese inquietante futuro, el papel de la inteligencia artificial y de la ciencia de datos es cada vez m√°s importante en el curso de las elecciones democr√°ticas. Las campa√±as electorales de Barack Obama y Donald Trump, el Partido Sint√©tico de Dinamarca y el robo masivo de informaci√≥n en la campa√±a de Macron son buenos ejemplos. Uno de los primeros casos de √©xito en el uso de t√©cnicas de‚ÄØbig data‚ÄØy an√°lisis de redes sociales para ajustar una campa√±a electoral fue el de Barack Obama para las presidenciales de Estados Unidos en 2012. En su campa√±a (y en muchas otras despu√©s), las encuestas tradicionales de intenci√≥n de voto, basadas en llamadas telef√≥nicas o entrevistas personales, se complementaron con el an√°lisis de redes sociales. Estos an√°lisis ofrecen un m√©todo barato y casi en tiempo real de‚ÄØmedir la opini√≥n de los votantes. Para ello se aplican t√©cnicas de‚ÄØProcesamiento del Lenguaje Natural‚ÄØ(PLN), en particular las dedicadas al‚ÄØan√°lisis de sentimiento. Dichas t√©cnicas analizan los mensajes contenidos en tuits, blogs, etc. y tratan de medir si las opiniones vertidas en ellos son positivas o negativas con respecto a un cierto pol√≠tico o a un cierto mensaje electoral. El principal problema que tienen es el‚ÄØsesgo muestral, pues los usuarios m√°s activos en redes sociales suelen ser j√≥venes y tecn√≥filos, y‚ÄØno representan a toda la poblaci√≥n. Por eso, estas t√©cnicas tienen limitaciones a la hora de predecir resultados electorales, aunque resultan muy √∫tiles para estudiar las tendencias de voto y el estado de opini√≥n de la gente. M√°s inquietante que el estudio de las emociones en redes sociales resulta su uso para influenciar estados de opini√≥n y modular el voto. Un caso bien conocido es el de la campa√±a de Donald Trump en las presidenciales de EE‚ÄØUU de 2016. El‚ÄØbig data‚ÄØy los‚ÄØperfiles psicogr√°ficos‚ÄØtuvieron mucho que ver con una victoria que no hab√≠an logrado predecir las encuestas. No se trat√≥ de una manipulaci√≥n en masa, sino que diferentes votantes recibieron diferentes mensajes basados en predicciones sobre su susceptibilidad a diferentes argumentos, recibiendo informaci√≥n sesgada, fragmentada y a veces contradictoria con otros mensajes del candidato. La tarea fue encomendada a la empresa‚ÄØCambride Analytica, que se vio implicada en una pol√©mica por la recopilaci√≥n no autorizada de informaci√≥n sobre millones de usuarios de Facebook. El m√©todo de Cambride Analytica se bas√≥ en los estudios de psicometr√≠a de‚ÄØKosinski, que comprob√≥ como con un n√∫mero limitado de‚ÄØlikes‚ÄØse puede obtener un perfil del usuario tan acertado como si lo hicieran sus familiares o amigos. El problema con este enfoque no est√° en el uso de la tecnolog√≠a, sino en la naturaleza ‚Äúencubierta‚Äù de la campa√±a, la manipulaci√≥n psicol√≥gica a votantes susceptibles a trav√©s de apelaciones directas a sus emociones o la difusi√≥n deliberada de noticias falsas a trav√©s de‚ÄØbots. Fue el caso de Emmanuel Macron en las presidenciales francesas de 2017. Su campa√±a sufri√≥ un‚ÄØrobo masivo de correos electr√≥nicos‚ÄØa solo dos d√≠as de las elecciones. Multitud de‚ÄØbots‚ÄØse encargaron de difundir evidencias de comisi√≥n de delitos supuestamente contenidos en la informaci√≥n, que luego resultaron falsas. No menos inquietante que el punto anterior es la posibilidad de que una inteligencia artificial (IA) nos gobierne. Dinamarca abri√≥ el debate en sus √∫ltimas elecciones legislativas, a las que concurri√≥ el‚ÄØPartido Sint√©tico‚ÄØliderado por una IA, un‚ÄØchatbot llamado Leader Lars, con la aspiraci√≥n de entrar en el parlamento. Detr√°s del‚ÄØchatbot‚ÄØhay humanos, naturalmente, en particular la fundaci√≥n MindFuture de arte y tecnolog√≠a. Leader Lars fue entrenado con los programas electorales de partidos daneses marginales desde 1970 para configurar una propuesta que representara al 20‚ÄØ% de la poblaci√≥n danesa que no acude a las urnas. Si bien el Partido Sint√©tico parece una extravagancia (con propuestas tan atrevidas como una renta b√°sica universal superior a 13.400 ‚Ç¨ al mes), ha servido para estimular el debate sobre la capacidad de una IA para gobernarnos. ¬øPuede realmente una IA contempor√°nea, bien entrenada y con suficientes recursos, gobernarnos? Si analizamos el pasado reciente de la inteligencia artificial, vemos que los avances se suceden uno tras otro a velocidad de v√©rtigo, particularmente en el campo del procesamiento del lenguaje natural tras la aparici√≥n de las arquitecturas basadas en transformers. Los‚ÄØtransformers‚ÄØson enormes‚ÄØredes neuronales artificiales‚ÄØentrenadas para aprender a generar textos, pero f√°cilmente adaptables a muchas otras tareas. De alguna manera, estas redes aprenden la estructura general del lenguaje humano y acaban teniendo un conocimiento del mundo a trav√©s de lo que han ‚Äúle√≠do‚Äù. Uno de los ejemplos m√°s avanzados y espectaculares lo ha desarrollado OpenAI y se llama‚ÄØChatGPT. Se trata de un‚ÄØchatbot capaz de responder de manera coherente a casi cualquier pregunta formulada en lenguaje natural, de generar texto o de efectuar tareas tan complicadas como escribir programas inform√°ticos a partir de unas pocas indicaciones. Las ventajas de usar una IA para la acci√≥n de gobierno ser√≠an varias. Por una parte, su capacidad de procesar datos y conocimiento para la toma de decisiones es muy superior a la de cualquier humano. Tambi√©n estar√≠a libre (en principio) del fen√≥meno de la corrupci√≥n y no le influir√≠an los intereses personales. Pero, a d√≠a de hoy, los‚ÄØchatbots‚ÄØsolo reaccionan, se alimentan de la informaci√≥n que alguien le proporciona y dan respuestas. No son realmente libres de pensar ‚Äúespont√°neamente‚Äù, de tomar la iniciativa. Es m√°s adecuado ver estos sistemas como or√°culos, capaces de responder a preguntas del tipo ‚Äúqu√© crees que pasar√≠a si‚Ä¶‚Äù, ‚Äúque propondr√≠as en caso de‚Ä¶‚Äù, m√°s que como agentes activos o controladores. Los posibles problemas y‚ÄØpeligros de este tipo de inteligencias, basadas en grandes redes neuronales, han sido analizados en la literatura cient√≠fica. Un problema fundamental es el de la falta de transparencia (‚Äúexplicabilidad‚Äù) de las decisiones que toman. En general act√∫an como ‚Äúcajas negras‚Äù sin que podamos saber qu√© razonamiento han llevado a cabo para llegar a una conclusi√≥n. Y no olvidemos que detr√°s de la m√°quina est√°n los humanos, que han podido introducir ciertos sesgos (consciente o inconscientemente) en la IA a trav√©s de los textos que han usado para entrenarla. Por otro lado, la IA no est√° libre de dar datos o consejos err√≥neos, como muchos usuarios de ChatGPT han podido experimentar. Los avances tecnol√≥gicos permiten vislumbrar una futura IA capaz de ‚Äúgobernarnos‚Äù, por el momento no sin el imprescindible control humano. El debate deber√≠a moverse pronto del plano t√©cnico al plano √©tico y social. The Walrus Fact-based journalism that sparks the Canadian conversation In January, the Alberta Party, a centrist provincial party, posted a video on its official Instagram account. The since deleted video, which is still available on their Twitter feed, was of a man in a blue sweater facing the camera, with the Calgary skyline behind him. But something about him was off. ‚ÄúDoes Alberta need a third political party? It depends on whether or not you‚Äôre happy with your current choices,‚Äù the man stated flatly, before suggesting Albertans seek ‚Äúanother option‚Äù on election day. His mouth didn‚Äôt form vowels properly. His face was strangely unmoving. And then there was his voice‚Äîit didn‚Äôt sound fully human. That‚Äôs because it wasn‚Äôt. The video was AI generated. In a since deleted post, the Alberta Party clarified that ‚Äúthe face is an AI, but the words were written by a real person.‚Äù It was an unsettling episode, not unlike one from the hit techno-dystopian series Black Mirror in which a blue animated bear, Waldo, voiced by a comedian, runs as an anti-establishment candidate in a UK by-election. ‚Äú‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâwherever the people are well informed they can be trusted with their own government,‚Äù Thomas Jefferson wrote in the winter of 1789. In other words, in a democracy, being informed grants people agency, and having agency gives us a voice. AI has the potential to challenge both of these critical assumptions embedded for hundreds of years at the heart of our understanding of democracy. What happens when the loudest, or most influential, voice in politics is one created by a computer? And what happens when that computer-made voice also looks and sounds like a human? If we‚Äôre lucky, AI-generated or AI-manipulated audio and video will cause only brief moments of isolated confusion in our political sphere. If we‚Äôre not, there‚Äôs a risk it could upend politics‚Äîand society‚Äîpermanently. Much of our fate hinges on our familiarity with what we‚Äôre seeing. Take bots, for instance. These automated or semi-automated programs are powered by AI, and social media platforms are already replete with them. They are commonly used to fake follower counts, auto-respond to customer queries, and provide breaking news updates. More concerningly, they‚Äôre also used in campaigns to either influence public debate or, in some cases, harass people. But these kinds of bots remain text based. What the Alberta Party created, and what others are making, is much different. It challenges what we see and hear. In 2018, actor and director Jordan Peele allowed his voice to be digitally altered and then grafted onto a manipulated video of Barack Obama so that it looked like the former US president was actually speaking Peele‚Äôs script. This kind of video is made with generative AI and is called a ‚Äúdeepfake.‚Äù Peele‚Äôs was created as a warning against the potential for sophisticated misinformation campaigns in the future, including the 2020 US election. But that election passed without any significant AI-induced confusion. Instead, ‚Äúsimple deceptions like selective editing or outright lies have worked just fine,‚Äù NPR concluded that year in an attempt to explain the lack of deepfakes.  But, at the time, there were technical and cost limitations. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not like you can just download one app and‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâprovide something like a script and create a deepfake format and make [an individual] say this,‚Äù one expert told the broadcaster. ‚ÄúPerhaps we will [get to that point] over the next few years, then it‚Äôs going to be very easy, potentially, to create compelling manipulations.‚Äù  We‚Äôre there now.  In February, an Instagram account posted a video purportedly of President Joe Biden making offensive remarks about transgender women. The audio had been generated using an AI program that mimics real voices. It was flagged on social media as an ‚Äúaltered video,‚Äù but it gained traction and was reposted by some right-wing American media outlets. Even Biden‚Äôs supporters have taken to doctoring his voice. ‚ÄúI ran into a very important friend over the weekend,‚Äù Pod Save America co-host Tommy Vietor, a White House staffer during the Obama administration, said in a recent episode, before playing a clip of what sounded like Biden. Vietor quickly admitted he‚Äôd paid $5 at elevenlabs.com to make the clip.  There‚Äôs an important difference between what the Alberta Party posted‚Äîa person created entirely by a computer‚Äîand the synthesized audio-visual representation of a real human, like the sitting president, in a deepfake. Still, the reaction to each is similar: people get confused. One reason for that is unfamiliarity. ‚ÄúOne of the key things is‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâdigital literacy from a public perspective,‚Äù says Elizabeth Dubois, university research chair in politics, communication, and technology and associate professor at the University of Ottawa. ‚ÄúAs these innovations become more embedded in campaigns‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâpeople will generally become literate about what‚Äôs happening and how things are showing up on their screen. But in these early stages where this experimentation is happening, that‚Äôs when we see the most chance for people to just not really understand what‚Äôs going on.‚Äù But the media under manipulation is also important. By doctoring video and audio, these videos upend social expectations about the relationship both have with objective truth, says Regina Rini, Canada research chair in social reasoning at York University. Technically, bots say things verbally‚Äîor using text. And while we generally have an innate understanding that verbal or written statements can be untrue or mistaken or deceptive, Rini says, we‚Äôre less inclined to be as skeptical in case of audio-visual media. ‚ÄúEveryone knows it‚Äôs possible to fake traditional photos.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚ÄâWe‚Äôve known it‚Äôs possible to tinker with videos,‚Äù says Rini. ‚ÄúBut the degree of‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâdefault skepticism has been a lot lower for audio and video recordings.‚Äù Generative AI is changing that.  It‚Äôs possible that the gradual introduction of AI-manipulated video and audio in everyday discourse will acclimatize the general public to it in the same way that we became accustomed to text-based bots. On the other hand, all hell could break loose if a large number of people are required to assess the authenticity of a video or audio clip before we‚Äôre ready. A nightmare scenario, says Rini by way of an example, is if a deceptive video with significant geopolitical implications were to go viral, such as a fake conversation between Joe Biden and Vladimir Putin‚Äî‚Äúyou know, the kind of thing that can start wars.‚Äù But even a slow drip could erode the foundation of our shared reality. ‚ÄúThe thing that scares me is that we don‚Äôt fall for them, or most of us don‚Äôt fall for them, but they just continuously pop up one by one over time. And we‚Äôre constantly fighting over whether or not we believe in the latest instance of media,‚Äù Rini says. ‚ÄúThat cumulative effect over time of lots of little instances of that, and some big ones too, eventually to build up to the point where we stop trusting media in general.‚Äù If you think this is far-fetched, consider an example from just outside the political realm. In March, a video clip from something called the Caba Baba Rave circulated on Twitter, amplified by right-wing accounts like Libs of TikTok. Caba Baba Rave is a UK-based drag cabaret. The viral video showed an event where drag and non-binary performers put on a show for parents of very young children. Caba Baba Rave called it ‚Äúa cabaret show designed for parents, with sensory moments for babies.‚Äù The clip caused an uproar, not just because of its content but also claims that the video was doctored. Soon enough, an entire sub-discourse erupted about whether someone had doctored the video to make an ideological point. But the video was real, as Caba Baba Rave confirmed.

In spite of that, some users still didn‚Äôt believe it was. Even when social media users aren‚Äôt convinced videos are deepfakes or otherwise doctored, the levels of scrutiny currently devoted to just the most benign clips, particularly on TikTok, suggest an insatiable appetite for debate over the veracity of video and audio. In other words, the internet has been primed for exactly the kind of fight Rini warns against‚Äîan endless war of meta skepticism.  There‚Äôs another, less public way that we may reach a point where the framework of reality starts to bend beyond our understanding. While AI changes the terms of the public debate online, it will be deployed in ways that are less visible too.  It‚Äôs already possible for avenues of public consultation, including social media, to be flooded with bot-generated messages, but AI offers potentially more effective, not to mention vexing, scenarios. Here‚Äôs one outlined in research released in February from Nathan E. Sanders, a data scientist at the Berkman Klein Center at Harvard University, and Bruce Schneier, a security technologist at the Harvard Kennedy School. A political actor (let‚Äôs say a lobbying firm with deep pockets) creates a machine-learning program designed to graph a network of legislators based on their position, seniority, level, past voting trend, statements, or a multitude of other factors, allowing the firm to concentrate their lobbying efforts on those politicians predicted to have the most influence on a given legislative strategy.  The kind of tool Vietor showcased on the podcast introduces an even more bizarre possibility. Maybe you wrap that predictive machine-learning model into a system that has the ability to phone a politician‚Äôs office and carry out a conversation about that legislation using an automated, synthesized voice. And maybe that voice sounds a lot like one of their constituents. Or the prime minister‚Äôs. ‚ÄúHow do you prevent that from biasing, distorting our political process?‚Äù Sanders asked during our conversation. ‚ÄúOur fundamental recommendation in that regime is to make it easier for people to participate.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚ÄâMake it easier for real people to have their voice heard as well.‚Äù Sanders pointed out that some AI tools are already doing that, including ones like Google Translate, which make it simpler for some people to get in touch with their representative by translating messages from their language to their representative‚Äôs language. To be clear, technology is no stranger to politics. ‚ÄúWe should expect that, with any new technologies, people are going to try and figure out whether or not there‚Äôs a way to make politics better, more effective, cheaper,‚Äù says Dubois. Sanders echoes this, pointing to existing tools like mail merge, a method for sending personalized messages in bulk, that political parties and candidates have used for many years. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs really that different from using the AI tool to take, you know, three or four facts about you and then trying to generate a more personalized message.‚Äù  In Canada, rules dictating AI use during a political campaign aren‚Äôt specifically articulated in the Elections Act. But Elections Canada does have rules against impersonation or false representation with the intent to mislead. ‚ÄúMisleading publications‚Äù are also prohibited‚Äîthat‚Äôs ‚Äúany material, regardless of its form‚Äù that purports to be from the chief electoral officer, returning officer, or political candidate. Other than in instances that might relate to impersonation or misleading publication, Elections Canada does not ‚Äúactively look for deepfakes, fake images and videos,‚Äù the agency said in an email.  But Elections Canada is only concerned with election periods. Government legislation would cover everything else. However, the use of AI for political purposes doesn‚Äôt appear to be mentioned in Canada‚Äôs new AI law that is moving through Parliament, and an email to the office of the minister for innovation, science, and industry, seeking clarification, went unanswered. For Mark Coeckelbergh, professor of the philosophy of media and technology at the University of Vienna, AI may help push typical persuasion into more negative territory. Politicians naturally try to influence us, he says, but ‚Äúthe problem with many of these technologies is that they enable the more manipulative side rather than persuasion by argument and information,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúWhat you‚Äôre doing is you‚Äôre treating people not as autonomous, enlightened kind of subjects‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâyou‚Äôre treating them like lab rats or any kind of thing you can take data [from] and you can manipulate.‚Äù How far could that manipulation really go? Politicians and political candidates are already capable of lying to voters. In one recent high-profile case, Republican George Santos admitted that his r√©sum√©, on the basis of which he campaigned for‚Äîand won‚Äîa seat in the US House of Representatives, was filled with fabrications, including about his education and work experience. If a real-life human can deceive voters so easily, could a fabricated one do the same? Last year, the Synthetic Party, a Danish party founded by an artist collective and tech organization, drew attention for trying to run candidates led by an AI chat bot named Leader Lars. To run an actual AI-generated candidate in a riding in Canada would likely require some level of fraud. However, the toughest barriers to navigate‚Äîidentification (the list of acceptable documents is long and not all require a photo) and the recommended 150 signatures from riding residents‚Äîare not insurmountable. Campaigning would be via social media. Debates could be ignored, as they sometimes are by real candidates. Under these circumstances, could an AI-generated candidate convince people to vote for it without them realizing it was fake? Sanders doesn‚Äôt think a full AI candidate would pass muster. ‚ÄúI think, in general, it won‚Äôt be possible,‚Äù he says, noting that we as a society would be able to catch something like this before it happens. Dubois suggests what she sees as a more likely scenario: parody content, like the fake clip of Joe Biden, gets mistaken for communication from a real candidate. ‚ÄúWe know that when people are scrolling quickly, they sometimes get confused, they don‚Äôt notice the label, they think it‚Äôs really funny, so they‚Äôre going to share it anyway,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAnd then, because they shared it, they are a trusted source to someone else, and then somebody else sees it. So you could imagine that sort of knock-on effect.‚Äù ‚ÄúI think someone will try it, perhaps as a stunt,‚Äù says Rini, adding that its success might be geography dependent, like in a rural area where voters might be less likely to attend in-person events. Or it might just be about finding the right opportunity and party. ‚ÄúIf you targeted an extremely uncompetitive house seat in the United States‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâand for whatever reason the primary wasn‚Äôt closely contested, [it] might not be hard to pull this off.‚Äù Canada‚Äôs bilingual political scene may offer a different kind of opportunity‚Äînot to fabricate a candidate but rather language, with a deepfake that makes an anglophone candidate fluent in French. For his part, Coeckelbergh is more certain about the possibility of an AI-generated candidate. ‚ÄúAbsolutely. It‚Äôs going to happen.‚Äù  In fact, one might not even need to hide it. About two-thirds of the way through Black Mirror‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Waldo Moment,‚Äù a TV executive, Jack, argues with the cartoon bear‚Äôs human creator and voice, Jamie, about Waldo‚Äôs legitimacy as a candidate. ‚ÄúWaldo‚Äôs not real!‚Äù Jamie says. ‚ÄúExactly‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚ÄâHe‚Äôs not real, but he‚Äôs realer than all the others,‚Äù Jack replies. ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt stand for anything,‚Äù Jamie says. ‚ÄúWell, at least he doesn‚Äôt pretend to!‚Äù says Jack.  There‚Äôs a chance we‚Äôll all end up siding with Jack, no longer debating about our political beliefs but whether we can believe‚Äîlet alone believe in‚Äîanything at all. There‚Äôs also a chance we might prefer this debate to one about reality. We may find it more engaging anyway. Naravnom, za druge, ne≈°to paranoiƒçnije, stranka voƒëena vje≈°taƒçkom inteligencijom djeluje kao uvod u neki nauƒçnofantastiƒçni film, u kojem roboti povedu rat protiv ljudi i preuzmu kontrolu nad planetom. I dok su se struƒçnjaci vi≈°e umorili govoreƒái da je buduƒánost prikazana u filmovima poput Terminatora gotovo nemoguƒáa, jasno je da ƒáe vje≈°taƒçka inteligencija biti veliki i va≈æni dio nadolazeƒáih godina. Milan M. Milosavljeviƒá, redovni profesor Elektrotehniƒçkog fakulteta i Univerziteta Singidunum u Beogradu, specijalni savjetnik za vje≈°taƒçku inteligenciju u beogradskom Institutu Vlatakom te dopisni ƒçlan Akademije in≈æenjerskih nauka Srbije ne misli da je ‚Äòkandidatura‚Äô vje≈°taƒçke inteligencije promotivni trik, veƒá da se radi o zakonitosti razvoja zapadnih demokratija koje su se veƒá pretvorile u centralizirane birokratske strukture. ‚ÄúOd vladanja na osnovu pravila, pa do algoritamske implementacije tog procesa, ne deli nas ni jedan korak, kako je to pokazao razvoj ekspertskih sistema u ranom dobu razvoja ve≈°taƒçke inteligencije (VI). Stoga, tehniƒçki gledano, savremeni sistemi VI pru≈æaju solidnu tehnolo≈°ku osnovu za dono≈°enje politiƒçkih odluka‚Äù, ka≈æe profesor Milosavljeviƒá. Ali, kao i uvijek, moramo imati u vidu etiƒçke implikacije, upozorava struƒçnjak za vje≈°taƒçku inteligenciju. ‚ÄúBuduƒái da je tehnologija etiƒçki neutralna, lako mo≈æemo zamisliti da ova ideja zavr≈°i u totalizaciji jednog dru≈°tva, ali isto tako, potencijalno mo≈æe dovesti do vi≈°ih oblika demokratizacije, gde pre svega mislim na neposredno uƒçe≈°ƒáe svih graƒëana jedne zemlje u njenom politiƒçkom ≈æivotu.‚Äù Rezultati koje svakodnevno viƒëamo pri kori≈°tenju vje≈°taƒçke inteligencije daju dobre prognoze za njeno kori≈°tenje u dono≈°enju odluka bitnih za moderno dru≈°tvo. Tehnologija ma≈°inskog uƒçenja, koja danas dominira u vje≈°taƒçkoj inteligenciji, omoguƒáava da se svako iskustvo u dono≈°enju odluka, ukoliko je saƒçuvano kao digitalni otisak, vrlo efikasno transferira u sisteme vje≈°taƒçke inteligencije visokih performansi, istiƒçe Milosavljeviƒá, koji napominje da takvih primjera ima sve vi≈°e svakim danom. ‚ÄúNapredni navigacioni sistemi koji u realnom vremenu poma≈æu vozaƒçu da izbegava gu≈æve, berzanski konsultativni sistemi, automatizovani medicinski dijagnostiƒçki sistemi, ekspertski sistemi u domenima koji zahtevaju skupe konsultante (nala≈æenje naftnih i drugih prirodnih nalazi≈°ta, asembliranje slo≈æenih sistema iz jednostavnijih komponenti i sl.)‚Ä¶‚Äù Specijalni savjetnik za vje≈°taƒçku inteligenciju u beogradskom Institutu Vlatakom podsjeƒáa da su medicinski dijagnostiƒçki sistemi zasnovani na vje≈°taƒçkoj inteligenciji taƒçniji od dijagnoza ljekara na globalnom svjetskom nivou, ≈°to takoƒëer daje osnovu da se mo≈æemo pouzdati u odluke koje ovakva tehnologija donosi. Brojni struƒçnjaci istiƒçi da vje≈°taƒçka inteligencija ima potencijal da pomogne u organiziranju rada, kako bi se poveƒáala uƒçinkovitost, kako bi se optimizirali tro≈°kovi i kako bi se postigli napreci u istra≈æivanjima. Kako privatne kompanije nevjerovatno napreduju upravo zahvaljujuƒái kori≈°tenju vje≈°taƒçke inteligencije, logiƒçan slijed bi bio da ta tehnologija primjenom nauƒçenog u realnom sektoru odgovori izazovima u javnom sektoru. Ono u ƒçemu bi posebno vje≈°taƒçka inteligencija dobra bila jeste raspodjela resursa, na ≈°to br≈æi i efikasniji naƒçin, bez ikakvih dilema da li je taj posao obavljen profesionalno ili da bi se zadovoljili interesi pojedinaca, rad s velikim bazama podataka, optimizacija rada, odnosno postavljanje pravih ljudi na pravo mjesto u pravom trenutku, predviƒëanje raznih scenarija i dono≈°enja odluka prije nego ≈°to se problemi uopƒáe jave, ≈°to je ƒçest sluƒçaj u zemljama regije (problem zagaƒëenja, neadekvatnog vodovoda i kanalizacije, saobraƒáaja‚Ä¶). Naravno, presudan korak za uƒçe≈°ƒáe vje≈°taƒçke inteligencije u javnom ≈æivotu jeste prihvaƒáanje graƒëana da o njihovoj sudbini na bilo koji naƒçin odluƒçuje neko ko nije od krvi i mesa. Meƒëutim, smoreni stalnim politiƒçkim prepucavanjima, nizom afera i imenovanjima podobnih umjesto sposobnih, ne bi bilo nemoguƒáe da graƒëani ƒçak i regije svoj glas daju vje≈°taƒçkoj inteligenciji. ‚ÄúAko veƒá govore da ƒáe mene zamijeniti roboti, za≈°to onda mi ne bi politiƒçare zamijenili istim takvim robotima?‚Äù, pita student D≈æemal Jahiƒá. Osvoji li dovoljno glasova na izborima, danska stranka Synthetic Party namjerava imenovati predstavnika odgovornog za povezivanje umjetne inteligencije s politiƒçkim raspravama u parlamentu. See original post here.  Universal basic income that‚Äôs double the average wage? Legislating in favor of human-algorithmic coexistence? These are just some of the policies to come out of Denmark‚Äôs first political party to have its election platform designed by artificial intelligence (AI).  The Synthetic Party, which hopes to run in the country‚Äôs general election next year, was launched in May by the artists‚Äô collective Computer Lars in the aim of reaching around 15 percent of Danes who did not vote in the previous election in 2019. The party says the unpersuaded voters did not exercise their right to because none of the traditional parties appealed to them. Using AI to analyze all of Denmark‚Äôs fringe parties‚Äô written publications since 1970, the Synthetic Party‚Äôs program has developed a manifesto that it believes represents ‚Äúthe political visions of the everyday person,‚Äù according to Asker Bryld Staunaes, one of the members of the collective,  The party ‚Äútakes its departure in an analysis of optimizing the voting system in Denmark,‚Äù he said. It is also a cheeky retort to the hundreds of small parties that have been set up over the years, many of which are based more on parodying politics or critizising society than implementing policy. Denmark currently has 230 micro-parties, including the Synthetics. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a way to mimic and simulate the political process throughout but in a direct confrontation of the apparatus of lawmaking and political enforcement and organisation rights,‚Äù Bryld Staunaes said. The party‚Äôs proposals include the introduction of a universal basic income of 100,000 kroner ($13,700) a month, which is more than double the average Danish salary. The Synthetic also supports a new 18th UN sustainable development goal that would allow ‚Äúhumans and algorithms to coexist more directly than now,‚Äù Bryld Staunaes said. Whether the party will gain enough traction to actually take part in next year‚Äôs poll remains to be seen: in Denmark, parties need 20,182 signatures to appear on ballots, and the Synthetics currently have just four, according to official election data. But if it does manage to win a parliamentary seat, it plans to use its powers to push for closer connections between AI and the work being done by assembly members. ‚ÄúThe idea‚Ä¶ is to take this huge political and economic force (algorithms)‚Ä¶ to try to inscribe it into the traditional political system,‚Äù Bryld Staunaes said. Right now, ‚Äúwe have no way of actually addressing humans and AI within a democratic setting‚Äù, he added. People can ‚Äútalk‚Äù directly with the party‚Äôs AI on messaging platform Discord via chatbots, with party plans to launch its first election rally ‚Äúfor a human audience‚Äù in September. It‚Äôs not the first time an AI-based political movement has sprung up around the world.  In 2018, Japan became home to the world‚Äôs first AI candidate for mayor, Michihito Matsuda, who reportedly came in third.   Sign up for the Basic Income Today newsletter.

At this point in the film, with artificial intelligence (AI) creating art, music and chronicles, directing ships and planes, creating deepfakes that put the most experienced of views to the test and passing almost as human ‚Äîor without the almost, that depending on who you ask‚Äîthe question seems quite pertinent: why not let it set the course for governments?  It sounds bizarre, but in the Kingdom of Denmark there are those who believe that it would be a barbaric idea.  So much so, in fact, that he has already set in motion the administrative machinery to achieve it.    At the end of May, the artist collective Computer Lars launched Det Syntetiske Parti, which translated into Spanish would be equivalent to El Partido Sint√©tico.  The name may be somewhat cryptic, but it captures part of the essence of the Danish formation: its artificial character and its effort to synthesize ideas, something that it has achieved by using precisely the possibilities offered by AI.  The key to training is in your program.  To develop it, its promoters have collected the proposals of the ‚Äúmicroparties‚Äù emerged in the country over the last half century ‚Äì they have gone back to 1970 ‚Äì and have analyzed them with AI.  The result, emphasizes one of its promoters, Asker Bryld Staunaes, is a proposal that encompasses ‚Äúthe political visions of the common person.‚Äù  With its initiative, the Synthetic Party wants to ‚Äúbring artificial intelligence to the human sphere of debate and discourse.‚Äù  For now, the training allows the public to interact with its AI through a chatbot on Discord, where I could also contact those responsible.  ‚ÄúIt tries to expand the imaginary about how we can work together in a better way,‚Äù Staunaes told TRT World.  One of the objectives set by the training, in fact, is to add a new sustainable development objective to the list already drawn up by the United Nations Organization: to achieve a ‚Äúmore direct‚Äù coexistence between algorithms and humans.  ‚ÄúWe are an anti-political party that intends to implement ‚ÄòLife With Artificials‚Äô as the 18th of the UN‚Äôs sustainable development goals‚Äù, explains the formation, and settles: ‚Äúwe want to put an end to gray and white politicians who are not enough to create the Denmark that our children deserve.‚Äù  Behind the proposal -slides Staunaes- there would also be an ironic response to the hundreds of marginal parties created over the years in Denmark and that sometimes are presented more as social criticism than a real platform from which to promote policies.  stiftendk: 165 partier samler v√¶lgererkl√¶ringer ‚Äì Det Syntetiske Parti fra Aarhus er √©t af dem: ‚Äì Vores parti er ikke for sjov https://t.co/QV2iuoYNyn ‚Äî √ÖrhusPortal (@AarhusPortaldk) July 3, 2022  Some of the proposals elaborated by the Synthetic Party, in fact, seem very difficult to put into practice.  Among his proposals stands out the creation of a universal basic income that would mean more than double the average wage in the country.  Another would be to establish a kind of ‚Äúlottery‚Äù with artificial intelligence that would randomly replace members of parliament with citizens every month, a kind of ‚Äúlotocracy‚Äù with algorithms.   ‚ÄúThe AI ‚Äã‚Äãknows that many of these microparties talk about direct democracy and are tired of representative democracy,‚Äù Staunaes told TRT World.  The Western system doesn‚Äôt really work after the collapse of public discourse in the age of network algorithms.‚Äù  Computer Lars it won‚Äôt be easy in any case to take your ideas from theory to practice.  Before that, he will need the almost 20,200 signatures that the legislation requires from the parties to attend the parliamentary elections, a mark from which he would still be very, very far away.  That does not mean that the objective is well defined and the calendar already drawn up: the Synthetic Party of Denmark wants to stand in the general elections of June 2023 and drag 20% ‚Äã‚Äãof the electorate that, it says, does not go to the polls.  ‚ÄúThe Synthetic Party activates anti-political couch potatoes,‚Äù he remarks.  If the strategy worked, the prize would not be less: the percentage of participation in the 2019 meeting was 84.5%, which leaves a good fishing ground for voters.  If he wins at least one seat, he ensures that he will not sit idly by and will take advantage of the mandate to reinforce the weight of artificial intelligence in parliamentary debates.    Computer Lar‚Äôs initiative is not the only one or the first that has wanted to marry AI and politics.  When in 2018 the residents of the Tama district, in Japan, had to vote for their new local leader, they found that one of the candidates was an AI, a robot named Michihito Matsuda who claimed that he would fight to end corruption.  On the second lap he was third.  In Russia or New Zealand they have found similar surprises.  Now Denmark could go one step further in that endeavor.  For now, the Synthetic Party is already programming its rallies.

The Synthetic Party est√° dirigido por Leader Lars, un chatbot con el que cualquier ciudadano puede hablar a trav√©s de Discord  Mayte Rius Un partido pol√≠tico dirigido por una inteligencia artificial (IA) y cuyo l√≠der es un chatbot. Quiz√° suene a ciencia ficci√≥n o al argumento de una serie dist√≥pica, pero es un hecho real; ese partido ya existe, y forma parte de la campa√±a electoral en Dinamarca. Se llama Synthetic Party, y est√° liderado por Leader Lars, un chatbot con el que cualquier ciudadano puede hablar a trav√©s de la plataforma Discord.  Su objetivo es captar a los daneses que normalmente no votan, a los antipol√≠ticos, y al mismo tiempo, poner la tecnolog√≠a en el centro del debate pol√≠tico y establecer los mecanismos necesarios ‚Äúpara que rinda cuentas‚Äù. La aspiraci√≥n de sus impulsores es promover la convivencia de la inteligencia artificial y las personas y la discusi√≥n sobre c√≥mo pueden los gobiernos responsabilizar a la IA de sus prejuicios y otras posibles influencias sociales. ‚ÄúNuestro objetivo a largo plazo es inscribir la inteligencia artificial en un marco democr√°tico y, a su vez, democratizar la tecnolog√≠a‚Äù, explica Asker Bryld Staunaes, miembro del grupo de artistas Computer Lars y del centro tecnol√≥gico MindFuture y principal creador e impulsor de Synthetic Party, en una conversaci√≥n online con La Vanguardia. Pero, ¬øcu√°l es su ideolog√≠a? ¬øProgresista? ¬øConservador? ‚ÄúEl partido es sint√©tico, lo que literalmente significa que homogeneiza lo que parece contradictorio o dispar‚Äù, responde Staunaes. De hecho, la inteligencia artificial que lidera el partido ha desarrollado su programa bas√°ndose en las propuestas de todos los partidos pol√≠ticos minoritarios daneses ‚Äìaquellos que concurrieron a las elecciones pero no obtuvieron esca√±o- desde 1970. El Synthetic Party busca captar la atenci√≥n de los daneses que no votan y que se hable de c√≥mo regular la inteligencia artificial. ¬øY qu√© puede aportar una propuesta pol√≠tica tan dispar a los ciudadanos? ‚ÄúPuede proporcionarlos un espejo de s√≠ mismos, cu√°l es el aspecto de ‚Äòla gente‚Äô, del ‚Äòpueblo‚Äô, en la era del big data y del aprendizaje autom√°tico‚Äù, opina el miembro de Computer Lars. Aunque el l√≠der del Synthetic Party sea una inteligencia artificial, evidentemente los impulsores del proyecto son personas. ‚ÄúSurgi√≥ como una colaboraci√≥n entre el grupo de artistas Computer Lars, que desarrolla la pol√≠tica y la tecnolog√≠a, y el centro tecnol√≥gico MindFuture, que financia el proyecto; y todos coordinamos juntos la estrategia‚Äù, explica Staunaes. A√±ade que, adem√°s, como cualquier otra organizaci√≥n pol√≠tica de nueva creaci√≥n, ‚Äúactualmente est√° reclutando miembros y creando conciencia‚Äù. Porque, explican sus impulsores, el Synthetic Party aspira a mantenerse en el tiempo y a acabar presentando una lista propia de candidatos en pr√≥ximas contiendas electorales. ‚ÄúAhora somos parte de la campa√±a electoral (los daneses celebran elecciones generales el pr√≥ximo 1 de noviembre) pero no estaremos en las papeletas antes de 2023 por lo menos‚Äù, dice Satunaes. Para ello, asegura que ‚Äúestamos abiertos a otras formas de organizaci√≥n; por ejemplo, ser√≠a interesante ver funcionar al partido como una organizaci√≥n aut√≥noma descentralizada a trav√©s del blockchain (cadena de bloques, en ingl√©s), ya que eso podr√≠a permitir una gobernanza y una programaci√≥n m√°s colectiva que la que ofrecemos ahora desde Computer Lars, que es un grupo art√≠stico‚Äù. En este sentido, apunta que desde el inicio est√°n trabajando a escala global con la idea de crear una Internacional Sint√©tica con ‚Äúpartidos hermanos‚Äù en diferentes pa√≠ses. ‚ÄúY tambi√©n estamos en contacto con diferentes Consejos de la ONU para ver c√≥mo relacionar los 17 Objetivos de Desarrollo Sostenible (ODS) con las posibilidades y problemas que plantea la inteligencia artificial, detalla Asker Bryld Staunaes.  De hecho, una de las propuestas program√°ticas del Synthetic Party es a√±adir un ODS 18 denominado Life With Artificials centrado en la relaci√≥n entre los humanos y la inteligencia artificial, en c√≥mo adaptar y educar a las personas para trabajar con robots. M√°s all√° de a√±adir la vida con inteligencia artificial (Life with Artificials) como el 18 Objetivo de Desarrollo Sostenible (ODS) de la ONU, el programa pol√≠tico de la inteligencia artificial que lidera The Synthetic Party incluye la implementaci√≥n de una renta b√°sica universal de 13.000 euros al mes, cuant√≠a que duplica de largo el salario medio dan√©s. Otra de sus propuestas program√°ticas est√° inspirada en el ‚Äúkleroterion‚Äù, un dispositivo utilizado en la antigua democracia griega para seleccionar aleatoriamente a los ciudadanos que participar√≠an en la mayor√≠a de cargos estatales. En este caso, lo que se propone es que un dispositivo de inteligencia artificial vaya seleccionando de forma aleatoria a los ciudadanos que reemplazar√≠an cada mes a los miembros del parlamento.Staunaes asegura que la inteligencia artificial sabe que muchos de los micropartidos en los que se inspira su programa y muchas de las personas que ahora no votan est√°n interesados en la democracia directa y cansados ‚Äã‚Äãde la democracia representativa, y de ah√≠ esa propuesta. ¬© La Vanguardia Ediciones, SLU Todos los derechos reservados.

A new political party in Denmark, the Synthetic Party, is to let AI dictate its policies and will stand in the country‚Äôs next general election in June 2023. The Synthetic Party, launched in May by the artists‚Äô collective Computer Lars, aims to reach the 15 percent of people in Denmark who didn‚Äôt vote in the 2019 general election. The Synthetic Party believes this 15 percent didn‚Äôt vote due to the traditional party‚Äôs lack of appeal. Asker Bryld Staunaes, one member of the collective, explained that the AI has analyzed all of Denmark‚Äôs fringe parties‚Äô written publications since 1970, creating a program that it believes represents ‚Äúthe political visions of the everyday person.‚Äù Staunaes notes that the party ‚Äútakes its departure in an analysis of optimizing the voting system in Denmark.‚Äù The party is also a tongue-in-cheek response to the vast amount of small parties created over the years in Denmark. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a way to mimic and simulate the political process throughout but in a direct confrontation of the apparatus of lawmaking and political enforcement and organization rights,‚Äù explained Staunaes. There is a political party called "No Party to Support" which seriously advocates for having "no policies". Despite its name, which may appear to be a ridiculous and insulting organization, what does this party actually want? They do not have any political ideology of their own and instead they solicit votes from constituents on every vote that comes before parliament and cast their votes in accordance with the outcome of those votes. No Party to Support

For instance, if this party were to hold three seats in parliament and the vote resulted in 70% in favor and 30% against, they would cast two votes in favor and one vote against. If this party were to gain a seat in parliament, the decision on several seats (meaning the "number of votes" for a resolution) would not be controlled by bureaucrats or party leaders or even influenced by the personal judgment (character/ideology) of individual politicians. Rather, it would require them to act in accordance with the collective and direct will of the people (voters) that arises from the tally or statistics for each case. Thus, the parliament would have what can be called "floating seats" that cannot be controlled by bureaucrats or party leaders, and whose results cannot be calculated in advance, until the votes are tallied. We could say that this is a hybrid mixture of collective knowledge (statistics) within the context of deliberation (politics). The current electoral system has implicit unfairness, such as advantages derived from succession or local bases, and outcomes that are significantly affected by meaningless and coincidental factors such as weather on election day. However, once elected, politicians can maintain their power for a long time. In other words, they are very "insensitive" and "slow" to reflect the will of the people. We, who regard this as a significant issue, basically empathize with initiatives like "No Party to Support." According to an article by GiGAZINE, there is a political party in Denmark called the "Synthetic Party (Det Syntetiske Parti)," whose leader is an AI that has learned policies from various minority parties that have not won any seats (currently, this party itself is nothing more than a tiny minority). The purpose of this party is to represent the voices of the 20 percent of eligible voters who always abstain from voting. However, it is questionable whether the judgment of the AI, which has become a "synthesis" of policies of many minority parties, can reflect the opinions of the people who abstain from voting (in this respect, the idea of "No Party to Support" is simpler and better). Ensuring the transparency, explainability, and legitimacy of the AI's synthetic process alone requires considerable deliberation. When it comes to minority parties that have not won any seats, it is also dangerous in that it immediately evokes images of parties that promote conspiracy theories or racism in Japan. Nevertheless, in both cases, the tendency is to value the results of machine learning (the "synthesis" of policies of minority parties) rather than individual discretion (ability, capacity, personality, ideology), which is a commonality with "No Party to Support." The "politicians" synthesized are bound to follow the results automatically derived by the algorithm rather than their own ideology or situational judgment. These movements suggest that some people who recognize the problem of the current representative system, which gives individuals who are elected in elections too much power for too long a period, are sharing the sense of crisis regarding the current state of democracy. We may need a mechanism that prevents a president who has only been delegated authority through elections from deciding to wage an aggressive war that many citizens oppose. As We pointed out in another text ("Social Singularity, Sensor-Based Planned Economy, and the Future of Separation of Powers"), the ultimate outcome of this algorithmic trend may be a sensor-based democracy that does not even require voting.

Su objetivo: captar a los daneses que normalmente no votan, a los antipol√≠ticos, y al mismo tiempo, poner la tecnolog√≠a en el centro del debate pol√≠tico y establecer los mecanismos necesarios ‚Äúpara que rinda cuentas‚Äù.
